We are grateful to the authors who graciously shared their previously data, to Gizem Yalcin and Eszter Kiss for their assistance with the meta-analysis, to Hang-Yee Chan and Danial Hayati for programming assistance, and to Michael DeKay and Joseph Goodman for helpful comments on earlier versions of this manuscript.

div.head: Years of Anchoring: A Meta-Analysis and Meta-Study of Anchoring Effects
Introduction
div.p: Each day, people estimate how long it will take to get to work, calculate how much to offer for a used car, guess how many others might be traveling to the airport, or consider the magnitude of various quantities. But, how do people decide how much they might be willing to pay for a bottle of whiskey, or what the wait time might be for entry into a concert venue, or how fast the newest Bugatti model might be? On what do people base their estimates? Contrary to a normative decision-making process in which individuals assign specific weights to informational inputs, carefully search their memory for all relevant information and potential numbers, and disregard incidental numbers, hundreds of studies suggest people in fact will incorporate clearly uninformative numbers when making numeric estimates.

The anchoring effect -the observed assimilation of judgments toward numbers present in the environment -has been a quintessential, highly studied example of bias in human judgments for half a century (see Tversky & Kahneman, 1974). The prevalence of research on the anchoring effect is due to its ubiquity in a vast array of judgment domains.

Past examples include general-knowledge questions (Jacowitz & Kahneman, 1995;Strack & Mussweiler, 1997;Turner & Schley, 2016), real-estate appraisers evaluating home prices (Northcraft & Neale, 1987), prices for consumer products (Ariely, Loewenstein, & Prelec, 2003;Green, Jacowitz, Kahneman, & McFadden, 1998;Simonson & Drolet, 2004), first-offers in negotiations (Galinsky & Mussweiler, 2001;Loschelder, Stuppi, & Trötschel, 2014;Mason, Lee, Wiley, & Ames, 2013), risk perceptions and probability judgments (Chapman & Johnson, 1999;Plous, 1989), advice (Rader, Soll, & Larrick, 2015), and even legal judgments (Englich, 2008;Glöckner & Englich, 2015). As is evidenced by the myriad of domains where the anchoring effect has been studied, its impact has extended far beyond its origins in psychology, into economics, marketing, management, law, medicine, among many more.

Despite the ubiquity of anchoring phenomena across a wide array of domains, there is no consensus about what the relevant moderators and boundary conditions are alongside numerous non-overlapping theories occupying the literature. In the current manuscript we aim to provide some organization to this important and expansive literature. In pursuit of this goal, the current investigation synthesizes predictions from the seven existing theories, offers a framework for categorizing existing mechanisms and moderators, meta-analyzes existing effect sizes, conducts a meta-study to evaluate conclusions from the meta-analysis, and offers directions for future research in this domain.

div.head: Paradigms of the Anchoring Effect
div.p: The original anchoring paradigm, which we refer to as "paradigm one", asked participants to judge whether a target quantity was greater or less than a random number.
In the canonical demonstration, experimenters presented participants with a spinning wheel that was rigged to land on the number 65 or 10 (Tversky & Kahneman, 1974).

Depending on the outcome of the pseudo-random process, participants were asked to answer whether the percent of African nations in the United Nations was greater than or less than 65% or 10%. Subsequently, participants provided a numerical estimate about the percentage of African nations in the United Nations. Results indicated an "anchoring effect," such that participants' median judgment was 45% when presented the 65%-anchor and 25% when presented the 10%-anchor.

One subset of the literature moved away from having participants explicitly evaluate the anchor and studied whether incidentally presented numbers would similarly influence estimates. We refer to this paradigm as "paradigm two". These numbers were entirely divorced from the target judgment. For example, Wilson, Houston, Etling, and Brekke (1996) presented participants with numeric strings (i.e., the anchors), in a presumably unrelated task, before participants completed a numeric judgment. Related, Critcher and Gilovich (2008) had participants estimate the menu prices at a restaurant named "Studio 17" versus a restaurant named "Studio 97'. In both cases, the only thread linking the anchors to the target judgment was temporal proximity (i.e., the numbers were presented moments before the focal judgment.

Other subsets of the literature instead examined cases for which the anchor has contextually diagnostic information (i.e., the anchor is normatively diagnostic for that decision context). We refer to this paradigm as "paradigm three". For example , Englich and Mussweiler (2001) found that judges' sentencing decisions were longer when prosecutors made longer sentencing requests (i.e., the anchor). Importantly, prosecutors do not select their sentencing requests at random. Quite to the contrary, these requests are typically informed by the case. Thus, using diagnostic information should be seen as normative. 1 Similarly, Northcraft and Neale (1987) found that real-estate agents estimates of home prices were higher when homes had higher listing prices (i.e., the anchor) than when they had lower listing prices. Again, sellers have diagnostic information relevant to the decision (e.g., conditions of the housing market, interest rates, similar recent sales) and imbue their listing prices with that normatively useful information.

Despite paradigms two and three being quite different from the canonical example from paradigm one, authors self-identify these as anchoring effects because the studies contained two elements common to paradigm one: 1) a numeric stimulus that appears before the judgment and 2) a pattern by which participants' judgments assimilated in the direction of these numeric stimuli. This very broad inclusion criteria is both what makes this literature highly impactful and generalizable but also conceptually complex.

div.head: A Brief Review of Existing Theories
div.p: The anchoring effect has accumulated at least seven different theories proposing underlying mechanisms that drive anchoring effects. 2 While there are a number of theoretical accounts that could be applied to anchoring (e.g., E. J. Johnson, Häubl, & Keinan, 2007;Schwarz, 1994), we focus on those that self-identify as distinct theories of anchoring effects.

div.head: Anchoring-and-Adjustment.
div.p: The core proposition of the original Anchoring-and-Adjustment theory is that when attending to an anchor stimulus, decision-makers begin with that anchor and adjust away from that value (Tversky & Kahneman, 1974). For example, in the context of judging percentage of African countries in the United Nations, people start at the 10% anchor then iteratively adjust the estimate upward, stopping periodically (e.g., at 20%) to evaluate whether that interim value is within the realm of plausible values.

The adjustment process ends via one of two mechanisms. The first mechanism supposes that adjustment is effortful, and decision-makers run out of their willingness to exert effort before adjusting all the way back to the true value (Epley & Gilovich, 2001. For example, a decision-maker may adjust up to 20% then reconsider whether this value is an appropriate guess about the percentage of African nations in the U.N. If the estimate is still too low, they repeat this process. Because this process is effortful, decision-makers may stop this adjustment prematurely ending at an estimate that is assimilated in the direction of the anchor stimulus.

The second mechanism asserts that decision-makers have some knowledge about the true value for the judgment and this knowledge is implied by a range of plausible values (Quattrone, Lawrence, Finkel, & Andrus, 1984). When anchors are outside of that plausible range, decision-makers adjust until they reach the boundaries of that plausible range. Because the decision-maker stops at the first value within this range, that first value is more likely to be closer to the starting anchor stimulus than to the middle of the range.

div.head: Numeric Priming.
div.p: Numeric Priming (Critcher & Gilovich, 2008;Reitsma-van Rooijen & Daamen, 2006;Wilson et al., 1996) contends that any stimulus activated in the environment can be encoded into short-term memory, and the activation of that stimulus can influence in subsequent judgments (Fazio, Sanbonmatsu, Powell, & Kardes, 1986). As such, numbers encountered in the decision environment, whether they are directly attended to via a comparison or indirectly as background features of the environment, become accessible in short-term memory and are then conflated when evaluating a target stimulus. In short, the anchor stimulus has a disproportionate salience in memory and thus contaminates the focal judgment.

div.head: Selective Accessibility Hypothesis.
div.p: The Selective Accessibility Hypothesis (Chapman & Johnson, 1999;Mussweiler & Strack, 1999;Strack & Mussweiler, 1997) suggests that when presented an anchoring question (e.g., "Is the Mississippi River greater than or less than 1,500 miles"), the decision-maker engages in a confirmatory hypothesis test about the possibility that the anchor is equal to the true value. When engaging in any confirmatory search, decision-makers selectively search for information that is consistent with the query (Klayman & Ha, 1987). Because this anchor-consistent knowledge is now in short-term memory due to this confirmatory search, that anchor-consistent knowledge biases judgments in the direction of the anchor value. 3

div.head: Attitudinal Perspective.
div.p: The Attitudinal Perspective applies the tenets of the elaboration likelihood model (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986) to the anchoring effect (Wegener, Petty, Blankenship, & Detweiler-Bedell, 2010). This theory contends that decision-makers can engage with anchors via a more deliberative central-route process whereby they engage in a process somewhat analogous to the Selective Accessibility Hypothesis (i.e., confirmatory reasoning about why the anchor is related to the true value). Alternatively, decision-makers can process anchors via a less-deliberative, peripheral-route process in which the stimulus acts as a prime analogous to the process described in the Numeric Priming account.
Additionally, this is the only account that explicitly argues that anchors can serve as diagnostic cues (Schwarz, 1994).

div.head: Scale Distortion Theory of Anchoring.
div.p: Rather than anchors changing decision-makers' perception of a focal stimulus, the Scale Distortion account suggests that anchors affect the internal scale decision-makers use to map their knowledge onto a numeric response (S. W. Frederick & Mochon, 2012;Mochon & Frederick, 2013). When making any numeric judgments, decision-makers have mapping knowledge (e.g., knowing that the Mississippi River is shorter than the width of the U.S. but longer than the height of the U.S.) and metric knowledge (e.g., knowing the major rivers tend to be longer than 1,000 miles, Brown & Siegler, 1993;Smith & Windschitl, 2015). That is, decision-makers can retrieve exemplars from memory that provide information about the ordinal position of a target stimulus relative to other comparable exemplars in memory (i.e., mapping knowledge) and exemplars that provide information about the cardinal quantity of that target stimulus (i.e., metric knowledge).

Scale Distortion argues that anchoring occurs not via mapping (e.g., a low anchor about the length of the Mississippi River should not make decision-makers think of the river as shorter relative to other rivers) but via a shift in the metric knowledge (i.e., a low anchor changes what numbers decision-makers will use to express the length of rivers in miles).

div.head: Extremeness Aversion.
div.p: According to Extremeness Aversion (Lewis, Gaertig, & Simmons, 2019), like in Anchoring-and-Adjustment, decision-makers begin at a presented anchor value and adjust away from the anchor. The authors propose an additional stopping mechanism to the two specified above: decision-makers stop adjusting when they feel that their adjustment from the anchor is too extreme (i.e., far away from the anchor).

div.head: Noise Theory.
div.p: The Noise Theory is centrally focused on the plausible range of values decision-makers evaluate when responding to an anchor (C.-Y. Lee & Morewedge, 2022).

The amount of noise in a decision-maker's representation maps onto how wide that range is. For a given anchor, any increase in noise in the representation will increase the anchoring effect. For example, higher magnitudes have greater noise, which translates into larger anchoring effects. Further, those with higher knowledge have less noisy representations, which reduces anchoring effects.

div.head: Interim Review: The Distribution of Phenomena and Theories
div.p: The above sections highlight several important qualities about this diverse literature. The first is in terms of the phenomenon itself. The anchoring literature appears to amalgamate a wide array of distinct phenomena under the umbrella of "anchoring" despite the fact that the psychological processes involved in incidental primes (e.g., Critcher & Gilovich, 2008) almost completely differ from the processes involved in more deliberative decision contexts (e.g., judges decisions Englich & Mussweiler, 2001). For the sake of this review, we incorporate this very wide and conceptually blurring categorization of anchoring, but we discourage readers from assuming that the different types of paradigms necessarily have common psychological antecedents.

The second insight pertains to our brief review of the theoretical landscape. The persistence of such a wide array of theories is likely because the theorists implicitly or explicitly recognized the above point -that there are different fundamental processes underlying different types of anchoring phenomena. And as such, different theories emerged to accommodate fundamentally different phenomena.

div.head: Theory-Based and Exploratory Moderators
div.p: The above section suggests that different paradigms and contexts were used to study different theories. For example, studies testing the anchoring-and-adjustment perspective involved largely different moderators than studies testing numeric priming (e.g., incentives versus mood). As such, the collection of moderators across the whole literature appears disjointed. In this section we attempt to offer a framework for categorizing the different design features across this wide literature. While some moderators within the literature pertain to specific cognitive processes (e.g., selective retrieval of anchor-consistent knowledge from memory) others moderators are not rooted in theoretical processes but are intended to be phenomenological (e.g., robustness of anchoring to the presence of incentives). Note, in our earlier discussion of the three general paradigms of anchoring we argued that similar patterns of behavior might reflect distinct processes. Because the goal of the meta-analysis is to integrate past literature, we treat paradigms two and three as moderators (i.e., primed/incidental anchors and contextualized diagnostic anchors, respectively) below rather than as separate meta-analyses and discuss their partitioning further in the General Discussion. Furthermore, paradigms two and three both include the same inclusion criteria for both the independent and dependent variables.

We categorize the different mechanisms from existing theories into four general sets of features that broadly integrate the existing theories: Salience, Inference Making, Memory Retrieval, and Depth of Information Processing. Note, Salience and Depth of Information Processing are not processes in of themselves, but act to change the amount (e.g., extent of elaboration) or type of (e.g., may increase/decrease the relative attention to the anchor stimulus compared to other features in the decision environment) information being processed. An overview of these four components, which moderators pertain to each, and which theories make predictions of which moderators is provided in Table 1.

div.head: Salience
div.p: One common feature of existing theories is the role of perceptual salience of the anchor in the judgment. 4 For example, Numeric Priming (Wilson et al., 1996) and the Attitudinal Perspective (Wegener et al., 2010) suppose that attending, albeit incidentally,

to anchors results in the anchor being active in working memory at the moment of the focal judgment. Anchoring-and-Adjustment (e.g., Quattrone et al., 1984) and Extremeness Aversion (Lewis et al., 2019) require attention to the anchor value for adjustment to begin.

That is, the adjustment process is effortful, so it requires deliberate attention to the anchor as a starting point. And, the Selective Accessibility Hypothesis (e.g., Strack & Mussweiler, 1997) requires the anchor to be attended to for there to be a confirmatory-hypothesis-testing process. Thus, the existing theories provide some consensus that anchoring effects must operate, in part, via attentional processes and features that alter attention (or the amount of information derived when attended to) should influence anchoring effects. One key difference between theories is in how much attention is required, and as such, moderators that influence the salience of the anchoring stimulus offer differential predictions. In the section below, we discuss relevant moderators.

Primed/Incidental Anchors. Incidental/Primed anchors (i.e., paradigm two) are anchors with no explicit relationship to the target judgment. For example, whether a restaurant is named Studio 17 or Studio 97 should not be diagnostic of its meal price.

Similarly, Wilson et al. (1996) presented participants with numeric strings, in a presumably unrelated task, before participants completed a numeric judgment. The Numeric Priming account supposes that increased exposure increases anchoring from these incidental anchors (Wilson et al., 1996). 5 While the authors of the Attitudinal Perspective do not specify it, we will assume that anchoring effects occurring via the central route (i.e., standard anchors) will on average be larger than anchoring effects via the peripheral route (i.e., basic anchoring/incidental anchors) because persuasion is, on average, stronger via the central route than via the peripheral route (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986). However, Scale Distortion argues that incidental anchors should not influence responses because they do not change the response scale (Mochon & Frederick, 2013). Similarly, the mechanisms for Anchoring-and-Adjustment are incompatible with incidental anchors as people need explicit anchors from which to adjust.

Temporal Delay. A temporal delay between the anchor and focal judgment may reduce the accessibility of an anchor in memory and thus its salience (Estes, 1955;Kahana, 2012). This delay may be achieved through minor changes such as a page break separating the presentation of the anchor stimulus and the target judgment to longer delays over the course of multiple days (e.g., Blankenship, Wegener, Petty, Detweiler-Bedell, & Macy, 2008;Mussweiler, 2001). Selective Accessibility contends anchoring will endure this delay due to self-generation of knowledge underlying anchoring (Mussweiler, 2001). Similarly, the Attitudinal Perspective argues anchoring has an even more persistent effect when occurring without (vs. with) cognitive load due to greater potential processing depth (Blankenship et 5 The Selective Accessibility Hypothesis assumes a confirmatory hypothesis test which implies some deliberation on the the anchor (Mussweiler & Strack, 1999;Strack & Mussweiler, 1997). At the same time, one of the original authors has also published evidence of subliminal priming of anchors which they argued was in line with the Selective Accessibility Hypothesis. We are unable to reconcile the explicit deliberation of the confirmatory-hypothesis-testing mechanism with the type of information processing involved in subliminal priming studies. As such, we have accounted for this apparent inconsistency in Table 1 with "NA" (i.e., no anchoring) to reflect the predictions implied by Strack and Mussweiler (1997) and ↓ to reflect the predictions from Mussweiler and Englich (2005).
al., 2008), though both cases exhibited anchoring effects after a week.

div.head: Inference Making
div.p: Decision-makers must process not only the focal stimulus, but the implied context by which a stimulus is presented. A canonical example of this is the attribute framing effect, where beef described as 75% lean leads to different favorability judgments than when it is described as 25% fat (Levin & Gaeth, 1988). The difference in judgments is produced not by the focal number (i.e., 75 vs. 25) but instead by the inferences the decision-maker can derive from the context (Hilton, 1995;Schwarz, 1994;Sher & McKenzie, 2006). The Attitudinal Perspective (Wegener et al., 2010) explicitly discusses the role of anchors being interpreted as inferential cues for the judgment. But, other accounts imply some inferential processes whereby decision-makers learn something from the anchor value. For example, in the Scale Distortion Theory, anchors inform decision-makers about how to map their knowledge from their own internal scale to a numeric response. And in the Selective Accessibility Hypothesis, the anchor provides information about where decision-makers should engage in a hypothesis test. This role of inference-making is also implicit in past anchoring researchers' attempts to create transparently random anchors (Ariely et al., 2003;S. Frederick, Mochon, & Savary, 2014;Tversky & Kahneman, 1974): the need for transparently random anchors is intended to minimize the likelihood that decision-makers are, or should be, actively learning from the anchor. The moderators in this section can be thought to influence the perceived informativeness of the anchor such that the context of the anchor signals whether decision-makers should or should not use the anchor value (Grice, 1975).

Comparison Question. Despite the original experimental setup attempting to present an uninformative anchor(e.g., spinning wheel of fortune Tversky & Kahneman, 1974), some have argued that conversational norms are still inferred by decision makers (Grice, 1975;Schwarz, 1994;Wegener et al., 2010). Directing attention to a random number and having participants compare that number to the target judgment (e.g., is

[TARGET] greater than or less than [ANCHOR]?) might signal that the number is in fact meaningful. If not conversational inferences directly, others have argued that these comparison questions can differentially activate information consistent with the anchor's value (Chapman & Johnson, 1999;Strack & Mussweiler, 1997). That is, people may elaborate on an anchor as a function of considering the comparison question, which makes the anchor salient according to Numeric Priming. What is common to these points is a potential impact of explicitly asking participants to engage in this comparison question before making the focal numeric judgment. 6 Different Stimulus/Dimensions Diagnositicity. This moderator changes whether the anchor concerns the target judgment or an irrelevant/different judgment (e.g., Harris & Speekenbrink, 2016). In the simplest case, the anchor is about the width of Brandenburg gate while the judgment is about the height of the gate (Strack & Mussweiler, 1997). Here the anchor and the target concern the same item (i.e., the gate), are on the same dimension (i.e., meters), but different attributes of the item (i.e., height vs. width).

A slightly more pronounced version of this is where the target item changes. For example, the anchor is about the time it takes to bake chicken and the target judgment is about the time it takes to bake brownies. Here, the only common element is the dimension (i.e., minutes). Another case is when the dimension changes. For example, participants were presented an anchor as a percent of account balance to pay, but made judgments about the amount to pay off in dollars instead of a percentage (Harris & Speekenbrink, 2016).

Selective Accessibility argues any of these stimulus/dimension mismatches reduce the magnitude of anchoring because anchor-consistent knowledge is less relevant to other 6 Notice that the only theory with a prediction in Table 1 is Numeric Priming. This is because while Selective Accessibility and the Attitudinal Theory both discuss how attention to the comparison question facilitate anchoring, they do not make explicit comparisons between conditions with and without the comparison question. Conversely, Wilson et al. (1996)'s Numeric Priming account makes explicit predictions in Study 2 whereby conditions without the comparison question operate via the Numeric-Priming mechanism and exhibit a small anchoring effect, and the condition with the explicit comparison question operates via activation similar to selective accessibility (Chapman & Johnson, 1999) and produces larger anchoring effects.

targets (Strack & Mussweiler, 1997), and Scale Distortion similarly suggests, due to scaling effects, anchors only influence responses when the anchor and target are on the same dimension (S. W. Frederick & Mochon, 2012).

Transparently Random Anchors. As mentioned above, a number of studies have implemented cues to deter decision-makers from inferring that there is implicit diagnostic information (Ariely et al., 2003;S. Frederick et al., 2014;Tversky & Kahneman, 1974). For example, some studies explicitly tell participants the anchors are random (Strack & Mussweiler, 1997). Others visually demonstrate randomness (e.g., rigged wheel of fortune such that participants would observe a seemingly random number being generated by the wheel, Tversky & Kahneman, 1974). Anchoring-and-Adjustment was first found using transparently-random anchors. Selective Accessibility argues that, even if anchors are transparently random, as long as they are on a relevant dimension, people will engage in confirmatory hypothesis testing that leads to anchoring (Strack & Mussweiler, 1997).

Contextualized Diagnostic Anchors. While anchors were initially conceptualized as transparently uninformative (e.g., Tversky & Kahneman, 1974), within paradigm three some operationalizations are necessarily imbued with decision-relevant information that decision-makers might pick up on. For example, it is logical for real-estate agents and prospective buyers to infer a home's value from the list price of the house (i.e., sellers do not set list prices at random Northcraft & Neale, 1987). The Attitudinal Perspective would argue anchors from more reliable sources should produce stronger anchoring (Wegener et al., 2010).

Directional Anchors. Directional anchors provide explicit instructions about which direction decision-makers must adjust to arrive at a numeric estimate (Simmons, LeBoeuf, & Nelson, 2010), and as such reduce uncertainty around how to use the anchor, increasing its informativeness. 7 For example, telling participants that the number of African nations in the United Nations is greater than 10% could provide more information than asking them whether the correct answer is above or below 10% because the direction implies a communicative signal from the experimenter to participant -this could be seen as a manifestation of demand effects (Orne, 1962). According to Anchoring-and-Adjustment, and by proxy Extremeness Aversion, directional anchors should decrease anchoring because they lower uncertainty about the correct direction of adjustment. This reduction enable adjustment in one direction that would feel less extreme and less effortful with respect to ascertaining how far to go since participants no longer need to do decide in what direction (Lewis et al., 2019;Simmons et al., 2010). However, there are also higher-order interactions with directionality that are beyond the scope of this meta-analysis (Epley & Gilovich, 2005.

Precise Anchors. Anchors can occur with varying levels of precision such as the number of significant digits or with rounded or non-rounded values (e.g., 3500 miles vs. Janiszewski & Uy, 2008;Jerez-Fernandez, Angulo, & Oppenheimer, 2014;Loschelder et al., 2014;Mason et al., 2013;Zhang & Schwarz, 2013). This effect has been argued through two separate mechanisms: scale granularity (Janiszewski & Uy, 2008) and conversational inferences (Jerez-Fernandez et al., 2014). According to the scale granularity account, because adjustment is effortful (Epley & Gilovich, 2001, if decision-makers adjust away from the anchor by X steps, precise anchors make the decision-maker's internal scale more granular, resulting in each adjustment step being smaller than in the case when the anchor is round. Thus, for a given X steps, the precise anchor will result in less total adjustment. The conversational inference explanation argues that anchors carry implied diagnostic information with them (Cialdini, Kallgren, & Reno, 1991;Grice, 1975).

div.head: miles,
div.p: When anchors are precise (vs. round), people find them more useful because of inferences about why the anchors are being communicated in a precise format (Loschelder et al., that is clearly too high to imply that the true answer must be lower Simmons et al., 2010). The former example was coded as directional but the latter was not because it would conflate the interpretation of the extreme-anchors moderator.
2014; Zhang & Schwarz, 2013).

Debiasing. Considerable effort has been made toward debiasing anchoring, though there is mixed evidence as to whether debiasing can fully attenuate (or even directionally reduce) the anchoring effect (Epley & Gilovich, 2005;Y.-H. Lee et al., 2016;Simonson & Drolet, 2004;Zhao, 2012). While there are different iterations of debiasing interventions in the literature, in general, many of these debiasing approaches encourage the decision-maker to consider alternative inferences for the judgment. In principle, a debiasing manipulation that, for example, warns participants about the anchoring effect (Wilson et al., 1996) or encourages them to consider alternatives (Mussweiler, Strack, & Pfeiffer, 2000) imply to the decision-maker something about how the anchor should be interpreted (i.e., changing the decision-maker's inferences about the anchor).

div.head: Decision-Maker's Memory
div.p: A decision-maker's memory is either explicitly or implicitly relevant to anchoring for most existing theories. For example, in Anchoring-and-Adjustment, decision-makers start at the anchor and iteratively adjust away until they reach the boundary of their range of plausible values (Quattrone et al., 1984). These plausible values are likely exemplars stored in memory. The Selective Accessibility Hypothesis (Mussweiler & Strack, 2000b) is predicated on the retrieval of anchor-consistent exemplars from memory. The Noise Theory (C.-Y. Lee & Morewedge, 2022) assumes that decision-makers have noisy representations of judgments in memory and the anchoring effect is driven by the amount of noise. The moderators in this section can be thought to influence the amount and type of information retrieved from memory when making judgments in the presence of anchors.

Anchor Extremity. Anchor extremity implies that, for a given level of anchor-relevant knowledge, anchor values further from the median belief will, on average, be perceived to be more extreme. For example, an anchor about the Chicago Bears scoring greater than or less than 85 points during the entire 2007 regular football season might seem reasonable to a non-football fan but might feel extremely low to an avid football fan with more judgment-relevant exemplars in memory (Smith, Windschitl, & Bruchmann, 2013). We categorize this under memory because the perception of extremity is derived by the decision-maker evaluating the anchor against values in their memory. If the anchor value is outside a plausible range (i.e., perceived to be too extreme), then it may be discounted for failing to match existing memory representations (Quattrone et al., 1984;Wegener, Petty, Detweiler-Bedell, & Jarvis, 2001). Extant theories mostly have predictions for this moderator. Anchoring-and-adjustment argues that more extreme anchors may increase anchoring as long as the anchors are within the decision-maker's range of plausible values. Once anchors are outside that range, people will adjust estimates back into the range (Quattrone et al., 1984). The Attitudinal Perspective, by contrast, suggests extreme anchors will be discounted and will produce weaker effects, yielding an inverse-U shape by which anchoring is less effective when the low and high anchors are extreme relative to not (Wegener et al., 2001). Extremeness Aversion contends people will cease adjustment when they feel they have moved too far, which leads to larger effect sizes as anchor extremity increases. Finally, according to he Noise Theory, higher magnitudes, which may be achieved at more extreme values, should widen the range of plausible values and thus increase anchoring.

Knowledge. Experts may have their own heuristics, schema, and background information (Alba & Hutchinson, 1987;Payne, Bettman, & Johnson, 1993), which may inform either the use of the correct answer (Wilson et al., 1996, Numeric Priming) or what values are considered within the range of possible values (Anchoring-and-Adjustment and Selective Accessibility Mussweiler & Strack, 2000a;Quattrone et al., 1984). Even if they do not know the exact answer, experts (relative to non-experts) might have a tighter (i.e., less noisy) distribution of plausible values (C.-Y. Lee & Morewedge, 2022, Noise Theory) or might use irrelevant anchor information less because they have a sufficient amount of information already to make the judgment (Smith et al., 2013;Turner & Schley, 2016).

Self-Generated Anchors. In the early 2000s, Gilovich (2001, 2006) argued that self-generated anchors were fundamentally different from experimenter-provided anchors. In these setups, participants may adjust to a final estimate from an internal anchor retrieved from their own memory. For example, when judging when George Washington became president of the United States, individuals may start from 1776, the signing of the Declaration of Independence, and then determine how many years later Washington was elected. 8

div.head: Depth of Information Processing.
div.p: The moderators in this section can be thought to influence the amount and type of information processing. The Numeric Priming account presumes anchoring effects occur via relatively effortless processes (Reitsma-van Rooijen & Daamen, 2006;Wilson et al., 1996), whereas Anchoring-and-Adjustment require an iterative (i.e., elaborative/effortful) decision process (Epley & Gilovich, 2001. The Attitudinal Perspective (Wegener et al., 2010) explicitly separates out anchoring via more and else deliberative processes.
Together, this implies that anchoring involves different processes (or that the consequences of a given process are different) under different levels of elaboration on the anchoring task.

Incentives. The impact of incentives is a popular moderator, particularly in the economics literature due to its substantive implications (Camerer & Hogarth, 1999;Hertwig & Ortmann, 2001), as there is variability in the extent to which decision-makers are motivated to provide "accurate" judgments. Researchers have applied explicit monetary incentives to motivate accurate judgments -with mixed evidence regarding whether monetary incentives reduce anchoring effects (Epley & Gilovich, 2005;Wright & Anderson, 1989). However, in principle, incentives may motivate effortful adjustment and decrease anchoring according to Anchoring-and-Adjustment. According to Numeric 8 Subsequently, Simmons et al. (2010) argued that the idiosyncrasies of self-generated anchors were not due to them being self-generated, but rather due to the fact that such anchors were directional (e.g., knowing the true answer for George Washington question was later than the signing of the Declaration of Independence).

Priming, incentives should decrease the anchoring effect (Wilson et al., 1996). The Attitudinal Perspective makes the opposite prediction because it conceives as anchors as persuasive messages and attitudes/beliefs formed via more central (i.e., elaborative) processes are stronger than those via more peripheral processes (Wegener et al., 2010).

Cognitive Load. While anchoring has been demonstrated in cases where decision-makers could allocate only minimal attention to the numbers (Reitsma-van Rooijen & Daamen, 2006), with some recent exceptions (Röseler et al., 2021), it nevertheless necessitates some processing resources on behalf of the decision-maker. We amalgamate two conceptually related moderators: cognitive load (e.g., keeping a string of letters in working memory while completing the task) and time pressure under the label "cognitive load" as both types of tasks reduce the extent to which decision-makers can utilize more deliberative processes. Anchoring-and-adjustment contends load should decrease effortful adjustment and thus increase anchoring (Epley & Gilovich, 2006). The Numeric Priming account argues cognitive load could increase anchoring if it diminishes consideration of alternative inputs and not the anchor itself (Reitsma-van Rooijen & Daamen, 2006). The Selective Accessibility Hypothesis suggests this boundary might change response times but not influence anchoring as long as confirmatory hypothesis-testing occurs (Englich, Mussweiler, & Strack, 2005). Finally, the Noise Theory posits that cognitive load increases noise and thus anchoring (C.-Y. Lee & Morewedge, 2022).

div.head: Mood.
div.p: In some anchoring paradigms, researchers manipulate participants' mood.

There are conflicting predictions. For example, Anchoring-and-Adjustment suggests that the greater processing depth induced by negative moods increases motivation to adjust from the anchor, decreasing the anchoring effect (Inbar & Gilovich, 2011). Conversely, the Selective Accessibility Hypothesis suggests that sad moods induce greater processing depth (Bodenhausen, Sheppard, & Kramer, 1994;Englich & Soder, 2009), and this greater processing increases the accessibility of anchor-consistent knowledge in working memory, producing larger anchoring effects.

div.head: Exploratory Moderators
div.p: We also investigated whether incidental study characteristics accounted for any variation in effect size.

Publication year. We examined whether effect sizes vary over time from when studies were first conducted to more recently. One common approach is to predict a decline effect by which effect sizes in a discipline become more muted over time, whether due to methodological refinement or for other reasons (Schooler, 2011).

Field. We examined how anchoring effect sizes varied over fields such as psychology, economics, business, and law, which all employ numeric anchors in quite different contexts. That is, in many psychology studies, participants view a numeric anchor prior to some quantity estimate (Strack & Mussweiler, 1997), whereas in business the stated or suggested price is the supposed anchor (Nunes & Boatwright, 2004).

Publication status. We assessed whether published studies have larger effect sizes than unpublished studies given unpublished studies may typically be those with nonsignificant p values. Alternatively, it is possible these unpublished studies were conceptual replications that obtained a significant anchoring effect but no moderation (Fanelli, Costas, & Ioannidis, 2017).

Laboratory studies vs. field experiments. We compared whether studies conducted in the field (e.g., M. H. Jung, Perfecto, & Nelson, 2016) differ from those from a more controlled behavioral laboratory (e.g., Epley & Gilovich, 2005).

Online or offline data collection. We compared whether studies conducted via an online platform such as Amazon Mechanical Turk or Prolific differ from studies collected from offline samples (Goodman & Paolacci, 2017).

Within-participant vs. between-participant experimental design. We compared the effect sizes of within-and between-participant designs. Note, this does not refer to within-participant designs for a given anchor (e.g., being presented a low anchor for the length of the Nile river before judging the length of the river, then presenting a high anchor before judging the length of the river a second time). Instead this moderator pertains to whether participants were presented multiple target judgments, each with one anchor. For example, Smith and Windschitl (2011) presented participants with a series of different target judgments with low and high anchors across different questions in cases with and without time pressure.

div.head: Participants from within or outside of the United States of America.
div.p: Consistent with recent research suggesting a possible United States bias in overestimating the size of research outcomes (Fanelli et al., 2017), we also compared effect sizes from studies collected on participants from the United States versus other countries.

div.head: The Present Investigation.
div.p: We report a meta-analysis and meta-study of the anchoring literature. We concentrate on comparing high against low anchors across 1,283 effect sizes in 479 studies in a primary database, and analyze additional forms of anchoring in the online appendices.
We then build on the meta-analysis with a meta-study in which we orthogonally manipulated numerous theoretically-and managerially-relevant moderators.

This meta-analysis builds on several related related meta-analyses in the same or similar domains. Anchoring is one of the most prototypical biases in the judgment-and-decision-making, behavioral-economics, and other related literatures, but has yet to receive as comprehensive a treatment as in the present manuscript. There are a couple meta-analyses exploring anchoring within in Law (Bystranowski, Janik, Próchnicki, & Skórska, 2021) and Economics (Li, Maniadis, & Sedikides, 2021)

div.head: Literature Search
div.p: We searched four databases and five different conferences for studies and papers in December 2017. We searched PsycINFO, EconLIT, and ERIC with the query: (anchor OR anchoring OR anchors) AND (judgment OR effect OR adjusting OR adjustment OR valuation). We also searched Web of Science's Social Sciences Citation Index (SSCI) and conference proceedings for social sciences and the humanities with TS=(anchor OR anchoring OR anchors) AND TS=(judgment OR effect OR adjustment OR adjusting OR valuation). These keywords were selected to hit anchoring and adjustment manuscripts based on initial exploration of key papers in the literature (see Online Appendix A on the manuscript's OSF page https://osf.io/d583s/?view_only=2f433256dd404a5ca83d703c1e1b4d99). In addition to the search query, we also examined three major projects that had replicated studies about numeric anchoring and the anchor-estimate gap that would not otherwise be picked up in a search string due to the cross-cutting nature of the manuscript text (Collaboration, 2015; R. Klein et al., 2014;R. A. Klein et al., 2018). Due to coding team limitations, we restricted articles to those communicable via English. This search procedure was updated in February 2024 with an additional round of literature search and unpublished studies elicitation via listservs (ACR, SJDM, SPUDM/EADM, Brunswik).

Two coders each examined all titles and abstracts for papers mentioning anchoring or related phenomenon in one round of screening in which they agreed 92% across the four databases. When this search was updated in February 2024, the two coders reached 91% agreement across the four databases. Those two coders then reviewed the papers in a

div.head: Inclusion Criteria
div.p: We primarily examined studies that fit the following criteria: 1. Numeric: Studies must have one numeric anchor between-participants with a low anchor and a high anchor.

2. Dependent measure: Studies must have at least one estimate in the form of a numeric estimate, whether it is a likelihood judgment, a price, or an estimate of an objectively-knowable quantity (e.g., the length of the Mississippi river) that is hypothesized to be influenced by an anchor in at least some conditions of the study.
3. One Anchor: We only include conditions or studies in which participants make each target judgment with one numeric anchor maximum.

div.head: Statistical sufficiency:
div.p: There is sufficient information, whether in the manuscript or through contacting the author, to calculate effect sizes.

We only used the first dependent measure due to potential spillover effects from multiple estimates from the same anchor. The cleanest estimate of the impact of numerical anchors on judgment is from the initial measures after exposure to the anchor. Subsequent estimates are less interpretable because participants may assimilate or contrast their prior response (Lockhead & King, 1983). Similarly, we removed any studies in which participants made the same target judgment (e.g., population of Chicago) with a low anchor and a high anchor because said judgment may be less about anchoring and more about updating priors (Chapman & Johnson, 1999;Mussweiler & Strack, 2000b, Study 5), or in which participants made titrated choices (Sugden, Zheng, & Zizzo, 2013). We also excluded a study in which external raters made inferences based on participants' actions (Mussweiler & Strack, 2000b, Study 3).

Per our "One Anchor" criteria, we excluded any studies in which there were multiple available anchors, whether as part of a range of possible values (e.g., is X between Anchor A and Anchor B? Janiszewski & Uy, 2008), or with multiple pieces of information that could be numeric anchors (e.g., high vs. low job offer salary plus job candidate's previous salary as a second potential anchor Crompton & Jeong, 2016;Galinsky & Mussweiler, 2001; Kristensen & Gärling, 2000;Northcraft & Neale, 1987;Thorsteinson, 2011). We also excluded any studies in which it was not possible to identify which dependent measure was first presented to participants (Ames & Mason, 2015;De Bruyn & Prokopec, 2013;Sailors & Heyman, 2019, e.g., the order of dependent measures was randomized). We excluded any studies in which there were not explicit numerical anchors (e.g., pictures of quantities;

Madzharov & Block, 2010, Study 4). We also excluded any studies in which the low and high anchor were identical but tied to different referents, such as in D. Sleeth-Keppler (2013), which used 45 years old as an anchor relative to Britney Spears or Clint Eastwood without a control condition. We did not include conditions with "free" as a low anchor as it is not technically a number (e.g., Palmeira & Srivastava, 2013), and we excluded conditions with ambiguous anchors (Schaerer, Swaab, & Galinsky, 2015, Study 1b).

We note that in some cases, the same anchor applied to multiple judgments about different targets. For example, in (Ariely et al., 2003), participants in the first study made six judgments for separate products with an anchor based on their social security number.

We included these cases as they still involve one numeric anchor per problem; that is, whereas multiple anchors shown for one problem was not admissible, having the same anchor for multiple problems was (noting it rarely occurred). However, we did not include judgments beyond the first one made when there was one anchor for multiple judgments about the same target (e.g., the value, initial offer, and willingness-to-pay in Wu, Cheng, & Lin, 2008, Study 1).

When studies included exactly three different anchor levels (e.g., low, medium, and high) aside from a no-anchor control, we excluded all "medium" anchor conditions, opting to include only the lowest and highest anchor conditions (e.g. Bartels, 2015;Dogerlioglu-Demir & Koçaş, 2015;Dowd & Artistico, 2016;M. H. Jung et al., 2016;Ma, Li, Shen, & Qiu, 2015). These "medium" anchor conditions occurred rarely. However, in cases with multiple levels of low/medium/high (e.g., extremely low, low, high, and extremely high), we created comparisons between low and high, and between extremely low and extremely high. For example, in O'Conor, Johannesson, and Johansson (1999), we paired starting bids $100 and $100,000, $1,000 and $50,000, $5,000 and $20,000, and $10,000 and $15,000. Because of the above inclusion criteria, cases with, for instance, a high and very high anchor, but no low or no-anchor conditions, were excluded (e.g., Mussweiler & Strack, 2000b, Study 4).
We used effect sizes from either the question level or from an index across questions.

Notably, several anchoring studies contain multiple anchoring questions that are occasionally averaged into a standardized index before analysis. When possible, we tried to acquire the results at the question-level (Smith et al., 2013); however, in other cases we had to use the index due to data availability (e.g., Wegener et al., 2001, Study 1a). We also excluded any studies that presented coefficients from a regression (Nunes & Boatwright, 2004) as these coefficients would not translate for effective comparison to the other effect sizes in the meta-analytic database.

div.head: Outlier Exclusions
div.p: After the literature search, open call, and requests to authors, and filtering via out inclusion criteria, we had 1306 effect sizes in our meta-analytic database. There were several empirical strategies for outliers. The primary approach we report in the main text excludes observations with a Cook's distance greater than (4/n − 2) (Cook, 1977). This resulted in the exclusion of 23 effect sizes, constituting 1.76% of observations in our focal database. This left 1,283 effect sizes. Further, concurrent with running data analyses, the authors also verified that the effect sizes from the top five and bottom five percentiles had been correctly calculated. In Online Appendix B, we also provide analyses (1) without exclusions, (2) excluding the bottom and top 2.5% of effect sizes, and (3) excluding effect-sizes from the large replication papers (Collaboration, 2015; R. Klein et al., 2014; R. A. Klein et al., 2018).

div.head: Meta-Analytic Methodology
div.p: We collected means, standard deviations, t-statistics, F ratios (which we converted to t-statistics), correlations, and provided effect size metrics (with small sample corrections) to estimate Hedges g and its inverse-variance weight using existing formulae (Borenstein, Hedges, Higgins, & Rothstein, 2021;B. T. Johnson & Eagly, 2014;Lipsey & Wilson, 2001). We calculated positive effect sizes to be those that had a high anchor mean larger than a low anchor mean.

In a limited number cases where explicit information was not available, we inferred cell sizes or standard deviations when said information was absent from a source or could not be obtained from the authors. In some cases, when means were presented as a standardized value, we assumed their standard deviation was one (Adaval & Wyer Jr, 2011;Bodenhausen, Gabriel, & Lineberger, 2000;Brewer, 2002;Epley & Gilovich, 2005;Jasper & Christman, 2005;Mussweiler, 2002;Mussweiler & Strack, 2001b;Strack & Mussweiler, 1997;Wegener et al., 2001), but we did not employ this assumption in some cases given skewed distributions (e.g., Epley & Gilovich, 2006). In other cases, we used the interaction term of 2x2 ANOVAs to calculate effect sizes across anchoring conditions (Morrow, 2002;Mussweiler & Englich, 2003;Mussweiler & Strack, 2000a;Sailors & Heyman, 2011;Strack & Mussweiler, 1997;Yan & Duclos, 2013). When cell sizes were unknown, we either used other information (e.g., available t-statistics) to determine what cell sizes would produce those t-statistics given the means and standard deviations (e.g., Mussweiler & Strack, 2001a), or assumed equal cell sizes (e.g., Hügelschäfer & Achtziger, 2014). In other cases, we used values in figures to determine effect sizes when said information was unavailable otherwise (Bermeitinger, 2014;Brewer & Chapman, 2002;Hans, Helm, & Reyna, 2018;Marchiori, Papies, & Klein, 2014;McGlone & Reed, 1998;Sailors & Heyman, 2011;D. P. Sleeth-Keppler, 2004;Smith & Windschitl, 2011;Smith et al., 2013;Wong & Kwong, 2000). Individual coding comments for studies are provided in the primary datafile on the manuscript's OSF page.

div.head: Additional Databases
div.p: The early demonstrations of anchoring involved comparing judgments in the presence of high versus low anchors. But over the years, researchers have broadened their investigations to several other experimental setups. In the main text we will present our meta-analysis of the common high-versus-low anchoring effects. In the Online Appendices, we provide three additional meta-analyses.

div.head: High/Low versus control.
div.p: The most obvious extension are cases whereby the high and/or low anchor judgment is compared to a no-anchor control condition (e.g., Cervone & Peake, 1986). We decided against amalgamating these high/low versus control effect sizes with the high versus low effect sizes because it is not necessarily the case that the control condition represents the midpoint between the high and low anchors in the primary database. As such, we believe it to be more prudent to separate the high/low-versus-control database from the primary high-versus-low database. We note that studies that had high, low, and control conditions were included in both meta-analyses. Given our Cook's distance criterion, we excluded 24 (4.5%) of the 537 effect sizes, leaving 513 effect sizes in 107 studies in this database.
Estimates of the average effect size and related analyses can be found Online Appendix C;
Moderator analyses can be found in Online Appendix F.

div.head: Correlations between anchors and judgments.
div.p: We also separately analyzed studies that used a range of anchors (e.g., the last two digits of a social security number or phone number) and correlated that distribution of anchors with the distribution of judgments (e.g., Ariely et al., 2003;Simonson & Drolet, 2004). While it is possible to collapse such study designs into a high versus low dichotomy (e.g., around 50 if from 0-100, Simonson & Drolet, 2004), that would require assumptions about the distribution of anchors, and more importantly, the distributions of responses. We calculated effect sizes in r when analyzing these continuous-anchor database, with Fisher's z adjustment, as this metric best represented the data (i.e., the relationship between anchor value and estimate value). This database had seven observation excluded (3.0%) based on Cook's distance (leaving 228 effect sizes in 40 studies). Estimates of the average effect size and related analyses can be found Online Appendix D; Moderator analyses can be found in Online Appendix G.

div.head: Anchor-estimate gaps.
div.p: Finally, we also coded studies that used anchor-estimate gaps in which there was an explicit, experimenter-provided, or implied, anchor against which an estimate could be compared (Epley & Gilovich, 2005;Inbar & Gilovich, 2011). Studies using the anchor-estimate gap measured the dispersion of judgments around the anchor rather than the influence of the anchor on mean judgments. We coded studies that either intended to study the anchor-estimate gap or provided individual-level comparisons of the subjects' estimates against the implied or provided anchor. While it is possible to subtract the anchor from the condition mean and label the resulting value as an anchor-estimate gap for studies that did not do this, that process makes untenable assumptions about the distribution of responses. Within those studies that used anchor-estimate gaps, 380 provided the raw deviations between the anchor and participants estimates and 204 provided standardized deviations. It is not straightforward to compare raw absolute deviations to standardized values because raw values, by definition, will have no values less than 0 whereas approximately half of standardized values will be less than 0. As such, we had to separate these effects into two separate databases and provide analyses for each individually. Given our Cook's distance criterion, we excluded 5 (1.3%) of the 380 effect sizes (leaving 375 in 44 studies) for the raw-anchor-estimate-gap database and none of the 204 effect sizes in 15 studies in the standardized-anchor-estimate-gap database. Because there is no baseline value for anchor-estimate gaps (i.e., they are used in the literature predominantly to evaluate anchoring moderators), we do not conduct an analysis of an average effect size for these databases but report moderator analyses in Online Appendix H.

div.head: Coding
div.p: The papers were divided among four coders, two of whom were the authors. At the time of coding, the coders ranged from a masters student to an associate professor. The authors worked with the other two coders to develop the coding sheet. The coders first began with a set of 9 training studies and feedback was provided directly after. Then, to establish reliability (see Online Appendix A for details) coders evaluated 16 studies with 53 observations (median κ = 0.662); a few variables with insufficient agreement were dropped.

The two authors had a median agreement of 1. In September 2021, the two authors reviewed all coding done and resolved any and all discrepancies, and coded six additional moderators in Spring 2024. Reliability for new moderators was established on 48 observations and reached sufficient levels (median κ = .803). The research team coded two types of moderators: theory-based moderators and exploratory moderators. The procedure for each coding, and the corresponding dummy variables are organized in Table 2, which also includes the counts for each variable level as superscripts. Priming/Basic Anchoring Whether or not studies used basic anchoring, in which a number is primed subliminally (e.g., Reitsma-van Rooijen & Daamen, 2006) or superliminally (e.g., Brewer & Chapman, 2003;Critcher & Gilovich, 2008;Wilson et al., 1996).
Not Priming/ Basic Anchor 1146
Priming or Basic Anchoring 137

div.head: Delay
div.p: Whether or not the study had a temporal delay between the anchor and the numeric estimate (e.g., Yoon & Fong, 2019).

div.head: No Delay 1275
div.p: Delay 8

Comparison Question Whether the study asked participants to consider whether the target judgment was greater than or less than a given anchor value before making the estimate (e.g., Jacowitz & Kahneman, 1995).

div.head: Comparison Question Used 970
div.p: No Comparison Question 313

Different Dimensions Whether or not the anchor came from an irrelevant dimension or source to the current (e.g., Strack & Mussweiler, 1997, Study 1) or was from a different scale (e.g., Harris & Speekenbrink, 2016;Wong & Kwong, 2000). Note, our coding in the meta-analysis included all incidental anchors as different dimensions (e.g., Critcher & Gilovich, 2008) because by definition the anchor concerns a different stimulus than the target judgment. However, to ensure we could separate these cases from incidental anchors, prior to analysis we recoded cases of priming=1 to have values of 0 for different stimulus/dimension coding.

div.head: Anchor and Target on Same Dimension 1224
div.p: Anchor and Target on Different Dimensions 59

Transparently Random Whether anchors were explicitly stated to be uninformative (e.g., Simmons et al., 2010, Study 1b), were uninformative as a result of being determined by a random or irrelevant number (e.g., last two digits of a participant's social security number, Ariely et al., 2003 Diagnostic Anchors Whether anchors came from a source assumed to be imbued with more information or not. These sources included real estate prices (Leib, Köbis, Shalvi, & Roskes, 2018), stated product prices (M. H. Jung et al., 2016;Smith et al., 2013) or salary offers (Thorsteinson, 2021), bank balances (Harris & Speekenbrink, 2016), and jury compensation or sentencing decisions (Chapman & Bornstein, 1996;Glöckner & Englich, 2015), so long as the anchors were experimenterprovided.

div.head: Diagnostic Anchor 70
div.p: Directional Anchors Whether the anchor was directional or not. For example, in paradigm one, participants evaluate if some target (e.g., the Mississippi river) is longer or shorter than an anchor before the numerical estimate of interest (i.e., the Mississippi river's length), which means participants can adjust upwards or downwards from the anchor. However, in many self-generated anchors (e.g., Epley & Gilovich, 2005) and some experimenter-provided anchors (e.g., Simmons et al., 2010), there is a clear direction (i.e., upwards or downwards) to adjust. Precise Anchors Whether studies involved precise or rounded anchors (see Janiszewski & Uy, 2008;Loschelder et al., 2014). When studies did not specify that the anchor was explicitly or implicitly defined as precise, we coded anchors as round.

div.head: Not Explicitly Precise Number 1279
div.p: Explicitly Intended to be Precise Number 4

div.head: Debiasing
div.p: Whether experimental conditions implemented a debiasing technique such as providing arguments against or discounting the anchor (Marchiori et al., 2014), using groups to debias (Meub & Proeger, 2018), or providing other tips (Hsee, Yang, & Li, 2019). Knowledge Whether or not participants had high question-relevant knowledge (e.g., Wilson et al., 1996). This was either explicitly stated or implied by authors.

div.head: Not High Knowledge Participants 1221
div.p: Explicitly Knowledgeable Participants 62

Extreme Anchors Whether study conditions used extreme or otherwise implausible anchors (e.g., Chapman & Bornstein, 1996;Wegener et al., 2001). This included observations whereby the original authors defined the anchor as "extreme" or "implausible", or when there were other anchor levels that were more moderate. For example, in O'Conor et al. 1999, we included four anchoring levels: $100, $1,000, $50,000 and $100,000. The authors do not explicitly define any anchor as moderate versus extreme, but given the stimuli, we categorized $100 and $100,000 as extreme anchors for our moderator analysis.

div.head: Not Explicitly Extreme 1234
div.p: Explicitly Defined as Extreme 49

Self-Generated Anchors Whether the anchor was self-generated (e.g., Epley & Gilovich, 2006) or experimenter-generated (e.g., Stanovich & West, 2008). Note, there were no observations in our primary meta-analysis but were in the anchor-estimate gap database reported in Online Appendix H.

div.head: Experimenter-Provided Anchor 1283
div.p: Self-Generated Anchor 0

div.head: Incentives
div.p: Whether or not the study had monetary incentives for accurate estimates (e.g., Maniadis, Tufano, & List, 2014).

div.head: Incentivized Judgment 101
div.p: Cognitive Load Whether conditions in studies employed cognitive load via time pressure (Smith & Windschitl, 2011) or otherwise (e.g., a secondary/distractor task, Blankenship et al., 2008). Study Type* Whether the study was conducted as a laboratory-type experiment (e.g., Strack & Mussweiler, 1997) or the field (M. H. Jung et al., 2016), or on Amazon Mechanical Turk (e.g., Lammers & Burgmer, 2017). We then split the sample into those studied conducted on an online platform or not, or in the field or not.

div.head: Laboratorytype 1257
div.p: Field 24
Online Data Collection* Whether the study was in person or via an online platform like Amazon Mechanical Turk (e.g., Lammers & Burgmer, 2017).

div.head: In-person 903
div.p: Online 380

Within-Subjects* Whether effect sizes were derived from cases where participants completed a within-participant task where they interact with multiple individual anchoring tasks (Blankenship et al., 2008;Bodenhausen et al., 2000) or whether participants only saw a single anchoring task (Critcher & Gilovich, 2008;Wong & Kwong, 2000).

div.head: Betweensubjects 1236
div.p: Withinsubjects 47
Country* Whether study participants were from the United States or elsewhere, as there may be differences between these samples (Fanelli et al., 2017).

div.head: United States 891
div.p: Other 392
Note. Superscripts indicate the number of effect sizes in the database for each dummy coding. * Indicates exploratory moderators.

div.head: Statistical Analyses
div.p: All data and reported statistical analyses can be found on the manuscript's OSF page: https://osf.io/d583s/?view_only=2f433256dd404a5ca83d703c1e1b4d99. To account for correlations among data as studies sometimes contained either multiple observations per person (e.g., Smith & Windschitl, 2011) or multiple conditions orthogonal to anchoring (e.g., Blankenship et al., 2008), data were analyzed using a three-level nested random effects models in which effect sizes were nested within study (Cheung, 2014). 9

Note, a standard random-effect meta-regression is considered two level because the variance is decomposed into variance within and variance between effect sizes. Further nesting the variance between-effect sizes within study (e.g., a given study used had multiple anchoring tasks) then adds a third layer. This is slightly different from the convention of "levels" in multilevel modeling with standard regression. Details with other model specifications (e.g., fixed effects, random effects without nesting, nesting with effect sizes at which errors are clustered at the study level) are available in Online Appendix B but yielded similar results.

We analyzed moderators using all univariate models, multivariate models controlling for all other theoretical and exploratory moderators, and univariate models among studies that contained variation on a moderator 10 . We also conducted moderator analyses controlling for publication bias methods (described below) and performed multiple other robustness checks under different model nesting structures (see Online Appendix E).

9 Dependence between any given effect size can be due to either/both 1) common-method bias from authors of the individual studies and/or 2) correlation induced by our sampling as the meta-analyst. For common-method bias, consider a given research team has a systematic bias in their methods/data collection. That bias will show up as a correlation between all of the effect sizes produced by that team. For meta-analytic sampling bias, if effect sizes are disproportionately sampled from papers that use a limited set of anchoring experimental settings (e.g., anchoring studies about the Mississippi River), the common study feature (i.e., Mississippi River) can produce correlation in the observed effect sizes. The three-level meta-analytic model aims to partition out these other types of study-level heterogeneity from the effect-size-level heterogeneity of interest.

10 These models are technically bivariate because they include an intercept and a single slope coefficient. We refer to them as univariate out of convention within the meta-analytic literature unpublished studies from reaching out to listservs and authors of the 200 we e-mailed who were asked for unpublished work. In total, we had 233 documents (180 in the high vs. low dataset).

div.head: Overall Effect Size
div.p: After our inclusion criteria and aforementioned outlier deletions, the literature search for high versus low anchors ultimately resulted in papers with studies and effect sizes (median number of effect sizes per study: 2). Overall, we observed a robust effect of anchoring when comparing high against low anchors (d = 0.824, 95% CI[0.765, 0.883], z = 27.428, p = < .001; Q = 19277.896, p = < .001); 55.03% of the total variation was between studies (τ 2 3 = 0.276) while 38.61% was within (τ 2 2 = 0.194) indicating that our three-level model accounted for approximately 93.64% of the variation in effect sizes.

We found similar or larger results when analyzing the data with a fixed effects model without weighting or nesting, a fixed effects model with weighting of the average effect size (but still without nesting), or a two-level random effects model (see Table 3). This table includes the overall effect size, 95% confidence intervals, and associated heterogeneity statistics (I 2 ) for each of these models. Notably, the I 2 statistic conveys what percentage of heterogeneity is not just due to sampling error (Harrer, Cuijpers, Furukawa, & Ebert, 2021). In this case, there is potentially little due to sampling error, though we caution I 2 is not a measure of absolute heterogeneity. Importantly, an overwhelming majority of effect sizes within this database are positive: only of (7.5%) effect sizes were negative. Note. Note. *** p <.001. FE Unweighted is a fixed-effect model with an unweighted average of the effect divided by outcomes in the k studies. FE Weighted is a similar model but with the weighted average based on inverse variances. RE is a standard two-level random effect meta-analytic model. The 3-level RE model is the primary model reported in the manuscript whereby effect size is nested within study.

div.head: Publication bias.
div.p: We employed numerous methods to address publication bias concerns that might emerge from such sources as selective reporting (i.e., only significant studies become published) and small-study effects (i.e., studies with smaller samples have larger effect sizes than those studies with larger samples) (Coburn & Vevea, 2015;Harrer et al., 2021;Peters, Sutton, Jones, Abrams, & Rushton, 2008). For the sake of parsimony, we provide a coarse description of our methods here in the main text, with additional details in subsequent footnotes and in Online Appendix B. First, as stated above, we solicited unpublished data to directly compare effect sizes in published data to those in unpublished data (Bediou et al., 2018). The key assumption is that the effect sizes from unpublished data (16.4% of the database) are approximately representative of the pertinent study features of the published data. To test this, we added a single moderator based on whether a given effect size came from a published study (coded as 0) or an unpublished study (coded as 1). Results If the true effect size is non-zero, then studies with large sample sizes should deviate from the true effect relatively little and both those with smaller and larger effect sizes are likely to be published (i.e., because there is sufficient statistical power to have a significant p-value with a small effect size). But, studies with small samples have an asymmetry.

Those with smaller (vs. larger) effect sizes likely do not have the statistical power to have a significant p-value and thus will be unlikely to be published. We test for this asymmetry by plotting the distribution of effect sizes (Begg & Mazumdar, 1994) on the x-axis against the standard error on the y-axis, where smaller standard error (i.e., larger sample sizes) values are higher on the axis. Figure 1 presents this contour-enhanced funnel plot, where the contours indicate areas where a given study's effect size and standard error should be nonsignificant, marginally significant, p < .05, or p < .01 (Palmer, Sutton, Peters, & Moreno, 2008). Next we evaluated asymmetries in the distribution of effect sizes using the Begg and Mazumdar (1994) (Palmer et al., 2008). That is, there are few effect sizes from small studies with near-zero or negative effect sizes.

div.head: Figure 1
div.p: Contour We calculated the average effect size under different publication-bias corrections, which yielded only modest adjustments downwards for most techniques. Figure 2 reports the results of trim-and-fill (Duval & Tweedie, 2000a of these bias-correction methods in Online Appendix B. The key insight is that across a range of moderate, conservative, and very conservative bias-correcting strategies, we observe relative stability of the average effect size.

div.head: Figure 2
div.p: Average Note. Note, results all correspond to the 2-Level Random Effect Model because publication-bias methods are not equipped yet for 3-level models. Error bars correspond to 95% confidence intervals on the parameter estimates. RE Meta Analysis refers to the two-level meta analysis. Unpublished is the same RE meta analysis but with a covariate coded as 0 for published effect sizes and 1 for unpublished effect sizes. Trim-and-Fill refers to simulating hypothetical effect sizes that would have existed without publication bias (Duval & Tweedie, 2000a. The Rücker et al. (2011) limit method is another simulation-based approach to estimate the hypothetical effect-size without publication bias. PET and PEESE are implemented analogously to the primary results in section . The Selection Step, Selection-Halfnorm, Selection-Logistic, and the Multi-step results all refer to selection models whereby a given effect size has some probability of being selected for publication based on its p-value (i.e., different hypothetical selection criterion among researchers and editorial teams that would produce publication bias).

div.head: Generality across disciplines.
div.p: The ubiquity of anchoring as a behavioral phenomenon is clearly evident in its presence across a myriad of fields. In Table 4, we present estimates from our three-level

We believe the relative change in Hedges' g in Figure 2 is indicative of what would be expected in a three-level model (i.e., we can use the relative decrease in effect size in our publication-bias correction technique as a proxy for interpreting our primary meta-analytic result). random-effect model on different subsets of effect sizes. Results indicate that the anchoring effect is remarkably robust across data sources. However, we discourage direct comparison of coefficients across literatures as study designs, participants, and procedures may be substantially different. We take the current results broadly as an indication of the robustness and generality of the phenomenon across a range of academic disciplines.

div.head: Summary: Overall Effect Size.
div.p: The above analyses highlight several important points. The first is that anchoring effect is large and robust, regardless of model specification (see 3. There is some evidence of publication bias, such that the effect sizes reduces by as much as half depending on which assumptions of publication bias we make (see Figure 2). This large overall effect is present across literatures, and even in unpublished datasets (see Table 4). More extensive analyses and publication bias details can be found in Online Appendix B. Analyses the other meta-analytic databases can be found in Online Appendices C and D. Note. *** p <.001

div.head: Moderator Analyses
div.p: A key with the numeric coding of each moderator is provided in Table 2 to facilitate interpretation of subsequent results. All dummy variables are coded 0 for the level of the moderator that was most prevalent in the literature. For example, most studies (i.e.,1146 effect sizes) do not use priming whereas a relatively smaller subset do (i.e., 137 effect sizes).

This way, all multivariate analyses can be interpreted with regard to the "average" empirical result in the literature. Overviews of the moderator analyses are provided in Tables 5 and 6. For the sake of parsimony we present a limited set of results here. Detailed analyses and results, as well an exploration of publication bias in moderator results can be found in Online Appendix E. and univariate models (second two columns). The left-most column presents our primary 3-level random effect model with effect size nested within study. We applied an additional step in our moderator analyses. Standard error calculations are based on assumptions of the dependence structure between effect sizes. This is often unknown and heterogeneity in that dependence structure can greatly increase Type-1 or Type-2 errors (Tipton, 2015).

Recent developments encourage the use of robust variance estimation for calculating standard errors on meta-analytic coefficients (Pustejovsky & Tipton, 2022). This is particularly important when considering moderators whose effect sizes are idiosyncratically nested within different subsets of the literature. All theoretically relevant moderator dummy variables were included simultaneously in this model so that the effect of a given moderator can be assessed controlling for the influence of other moderators. 13 The next column includes all of the theoretical moderators plus the exploratory moderators as controls. The last two columns are univariate analyses in which effect size is regressed on each moderator individually. In the first of the two univariate columns, each model estimates the effect of the moderator using the full 1,283 effect sizes. Many studies only include a single level of a given moderator. As such, in the last column we subset the data to those studies which included both levels of a given moderator (i.e., the moderator was experimentally manipulated within that study) -sample sizes for those subsets are included in Table 6. 14 In Table 6, we calculated the results of the univariate models in the two righthand columns of Table 5 in terms of their effect size for each level of the dummy variables. For each univariate model we took the intercept to reflect the anchoring effect when that 13 In our primary meta analysis here, there were no observations with self-generated anchors, as such it will not be included in the subsequent analyses. These effects are primarily studied in paradigms using the anchor-estimate gaps (see Online Appendix H) moderator is coded 0 and the coefficient on the moderator term to be the change in the effect size for a one-unit change in the moderator. For example, because moderators were coded as 0 and 1, the coefficients in Table 6 can be interpreted as the change in Hedges' g between the levels of that moderator. Note the intercepts in these models are all different and not directly interpretable in the case of the multivariate models. The first column the primary three-level model with effect size nested in study which is nested within paper. The second column is controls for the exploratory moderators. The following column presents results for a series of univariate models with the three-level random effect nesting structure.
