The last column repeats the univariate models, but rather than utilizing the total database in each model, it instead subsets the data to only include studies that had both levels of a given moderator.

div.head: Salience.
div.p: Priming/Basic Anchoring. Results indicated substantially smaller effect sizes for primed/basic anchors compared to the majority of anchoring studies with coefficients ranging between -0.72 and -0.89 in Table 5. Table 6 presents the results of the univariate models from (Strack & Mussweiler, 1997) or implies some diagnostic cue to the participant (Schwarz, 1994), the literature has prioritized the use of these comparison questions as the delivery system for anchors in 73.7% of our database. Understanding the moderating impact of this comparison question is difficult because this variable correlates with several other variables. Both multivariate models indicate a sizeable reduction in the effect size when the anchor is presented as transparently random (β's -0.27 and -0.31). Surprisingly, both the univariate models did not indicate moderation. We would caution from interpreting the univariate model in column 4 of Table 5. Despite transparently random anchors being used in 22.2% of our primary database, we only found 8 effect sizes in total where this highly prevalent feature of the anchoring literature was manipulated within a study.

Contextually Diagnostic Anchors. We found no reliable difference for contextually diagnostic anchors (β's -0.16 to 0.28). Similar to the previous case, we would discourage interpretation of the results of the univariate subset analysis because we only had 4 effect sizes where the anchor was manipulated to be more diagnostic. The rest of the results in Table 5 suggest that contextually diagnostic anchors produce smaller anchoring effects than anchors rendered non-diagnostic through transparent randomness or different dimensions. This appears contradictory to the above results in this inference-making section -where reducing the relevance of the anchor by having it on a different dimension as the target or making it transparently random reduces the anchor, making it more relevant by it being in a diagnostic context should increase the size of the anchoring effect. This result can be interpreted in one of two ways. Either there exists some inverse U-shaped relationship with inference making, or there exists some potential omitted variable bias related to paradigm three such that there are other features of studies (i.e., the other contextualizing information in the study design separate from the anchor value) that reduce the effect size that are not included in this meta-analysis. when anchors are precise than when they are round (e.g., Janiszewski & Uy, 2008;Mason et al., 2013;Zhang & Schwarz, 2013), meta-analytic evidence suggests only weak and inconsistent when the anchor is precise compared to round. The wide confidence intervals on these estimates reflects the relatively few observations of anchor precision in the database -there are considerably more in the anchor-estimate-gap database reported in Online Appendix H.

Debiasing. Meta-analytic results indicate consistent decreases in the magnitude of the anchoring effect for studies where a debiasing manipulation was applied (β's -0.37 to -0.17). This is consistent with a range of judgment and decision-making biases that are reduced by debiasing strategies (Morewedge et al., 2015).

div.head: Memory.
div.p: Extreme Anchors. Results consistently revealed little evidence (β's -0.02 to 0.09) of extreme anchors influencing the effect size. This null result could be interpreted in two ways: that the extremity of the anchor does not impact the psychological processes involved in anchoring, or our coding of extremity -which is based on authors' implied or explicit labeling of the anchors as extreme in their text -does not sufficiently capture the latent construct of extremity.

Knowledge. Meta-analytic results indicate a small and relatively consistent decreases in the magnitude of the anchoring effect for cases where participants were more knowledgeable about the target judgment (β's -0.21 to -0.14). Note from Table 6 that while anchoring effects are smaller for those who are more knowledgeable (e.g., experts in a target judgment domain), the coefficients are still quite large and reliable among knowledgeable decision-makers implying that anchoring still persists among both non-experts and experts -though to varying degrees.

div.head: Depth of Information Processing.
div.p: Incentives. Meta-analytic results indicate consistent decreases in the magnitude of the anchoring effect for studies where an incentive was applied to decision-maker's accuracy (β's -0.24 to -0.23).

div.head: Cognitive-Load.
div.p: We observe little evidence (β's -0.06 to -0.02) of cognitive-load on the magnitude of the anchoring effect. Results were consistent for this moderator.

div.head: Mood.
div.p: Results were relatively consistent across models (β's -0.35 to -0.15), though estimates had relatively wide confidence intervals due to the few observations of this particular moderator. Note, we code all negative emotions within this moderator, so the weak evidence of an attenuation should not be interpreted with regard to any other emotion.

div.head: Publication Bias in Moderator Analyses
div.p: Publication bias has been explored in estimates of aggregate effect sizes (for a review see McShane, Böckenholt, & Hansen, 2016), but limited attention has been paid to corrections of estimates of moderators(for an initial overview, see Coburn & Vevea, 2015).

This makes sense given that most meta-analyses are not large enough to engage in a thorough exploration of the moderator space. In contrast, our meta-analysis provides a sufficient quantity of observations and diversity of moderators to engage in an analysis of publication bias of each moderator. We adapted existing selection-model techniques to all of the models presented in Table 5, but using only a 2-level versions of the models as higher-level models are not equipped to handle these publication-bias tools. We then applied two versions of single-step (McShane et al., 2016), and four versions of multi-step (Vevea & Woods, 2005) selection models to account for publication bias. Overall, the results for publication-bias corrections were largely consistent with the uncorrected parameters -suggesting that our above results are unlikely the consequence of selective reporting based on p-value. Full methodological detail and results are outlined in Online Appendix E.

div.head: Summary: Moderator Analyses.
div.p: As stated above, we avoid the dichotomization of null hypothesis testing and rather focus on a quantitative assessment of relative effect sizes. Results of salience-related moderators suggest that in general there is some evidence that decreased attention to the anchoring stimulus -either because the stimulus was presented as a prime/incidentally or via a time delay between presentation of the anchor and the judgment -likely reduces the magnitude of the anchoring effect. Notably, primed/incidental anchors are the only moderator that potentially eliminates the anchoring effect. Said another way, priming anchors, if they produce anchoring effect, result in negligible or very small impacts on judgments. Across the different inference-making-related moderators, results are mostly consistent with Schwarz (1994): anchors might have conversational cues to decision-makers who interpret the anchors as diagnostic to the focal judgment. Reducing the diagnosticity of these cues was associated with reduced effect sizes. While we did not observe any consistent evidence of anchor extremity on the magnitude of the anchoring effect, we caution that this may be due to the limited ability to code for extremity across the papers because the majority of papers do not provide calibration information to interpret the extent of extremity. Consistent with Smith et al. (2013), decision-makers who were more knowledgeable about the target judgment exhibited smaller anchoring effects. For information-processing-related moderators, we find that only incentives reliably reduce the anchoring effect, but acknowledge some systematic reductions for negative-emotion studies that warrant further investigation. More extensive moderator analyses and publication bias details can be found in Online Appendix E. Moderator analyses for the other meta-analytic databases can be found in Online Appendices F-H.

div.head: Meta-Study
div.p: To supplement our review and synthesis of the anchoring literature, we also conducted a meta-study (for reviews on meta-studies see Baribault et al., 2018;DeKay, Rubinchik, Li, & De Boeck, 2022). While meta-analysis is a powerful tool for efficiently summarizing the literature, 1) it is correlational in nature, 2) it can lack orthogonality and comparability across effect sizes, and 3) it faces concerns with publication bias.
Meta-studies offer an environment for testing orthogonal moderators, and a pre-registered meta-study eliminates the concern of publication bias.
Anchoring provides a strong opportunity to test moderation of the effect of interest.

Meta-studies begin with a core design around the effect of interest. In this case, our core design will be the manipulation of high versus low anchors for a set of general knowledge questions (e.g., Jacowitz & Kahneman, 1995). We then manipulate each of these moderators across this core design. These moderators are embedded as a micro-study within a singular large orthogonal structure. Moderators are included as within-or between-participant factors in the meta-study design. The procedure, participants, experimental design and primary statistical analyses were pre-registered and can be found at (AsPredicted #141242) https://aspredicted.org/Y51_336. All meta-study materials, data, analyses, as well as additional robustness checks are provided in Online Appendix I on the manuscript's OSF page:
https://osf.io/9yduf?view_only=2f433256dd404a5ca83d703c1e1b4d99).

div.head: Participants.
div.p: We recruited 2001 U.S. adults from Prolific in August 2023 in exchange for ($1.60) and randomly assigned them to condition (see Method section below for experimental design). We excluded 33 responses who failed any one of three pre-registered attention checks. The final sample included 1,968 US adults (M age = 40.71 years, IQR = 20, 825 female, 1098 male, 37 non-binary/third gender, and 8 preferred not to specify).

div.head: Procedure.
div.p: Participants completed eight anchoring questions in a random order (see Table 7).

In the meta-study, for each of the eight items, participants first saw a numeric anchor, then saw an image containing the anchoring item's text for their numeric estimate. This image was intended to reduce the probability that participants searched for the answer online by copying and pasting the question text. Then, lastly, participants indicated their subjective knowledge from 1 (not at all knowledgeable) to 7 (extremely knowledgeable) on a subsequent page.

div.head: Experimental Design
div.p: We included as many moderators as possible based on which moderators could operate independently of each other. Meta-studies are predicated on an assumption that the effects of any given moderator are independent of other moderators in the study design (Baribault et al., 2018;DeKay et al., 2022). This assumption limits the potential anchoring moderators that could be included. We incorporated moderators within-or between-participant if they were unlikely to violate independence across the other conditions of the meta-study. For instance, it would be difficult to manipulate anchor stimulus and directionality orthogonal to whether the anchor is a primed anchor or not.
That is, while some moderators could easily be applied to standard anchoring tasks, it is not straightforward how to apply these moderators across numeric primes.

Within-subjects we manipulated whether anchors were more precise (i.e., had a .00 at the end of the number or not), and anchor extremity (whether the participants saw the 3rd/97th, 15th/85th, or 30th/70th percentiles). That is, across the eight different anchoring questions, participants could see more or less extreme, high or low, and more or less precise anchors. We also measured subjective knowledge for each question.

Between-subjects we manipulated the presence of cognitive load (i.e., whether or not a load task requesting retention of a letter string was present), debiasing instructions (i.e., whether or not participants were told at the start of the study and before each judgment to avoid anchoring), incentives (i.e., whether or not participants learned they could receive a $0.50 bonus for being within the 10% closest on a randomly-selected judgment), delay (i.e., whether or not there was a page break between the numeric anchor and estimate), directional anchors (i.e., whether the anchor was in a comparative question to which the participants responded, or stated the target value was greater or less than the anchor), and diagnosticity in terms of different target stimulus (e.g., asking the anchor in the context of brownie-baking or chicken-cooking prior to a numeric estimate about brownie-baking). Full details of the experimental design, including how each moderator was operationalized, can be found in Online Appendix I.

div.head: Meta-Study Analysis and Results
div.p: In line with our pre-registration, for each anchoring question we winsorized the data at the 95th percentile (i.e., the bottom and top 2.5% of responses). 15 Responses for each anchor item were z-scored within item to equate different scales across judgments (e.g., numbers of calories will have responses much greater than number of U2 studio albums released), such that the mean of each anchoring question in Table 7 is 0 with a standard deviation of 1. All binary moderator variables were dummy coded then mean-centered, such that the intercept reflects the average level of the two conditions. Anchor extremity was coded with a linear-effects coding such that the less extreme anchors (i.e., 30th and 70th percentiles) were coded -0.5, the moderate anchors (i.e., 15th and 85th percentiles) were coded 0, and extreme anchors (i.e., 3rd and 97th percentiles) were coded 0.5. Additionally, we included a quadratic coding for extremity as well (i.e., -0.66, 0.33). Knowledge was treated as a continuous variable but median split only for graphical purposes.

Because conditions of the meta-study are manipulated orthogonally to the anchor item, we can take the z-scored responses (scaled within anchor item) and compute the average scaled estimate for the low and high anchor conditions for each condition of the meta-study design. In Figure 3, we present the mean estimates and 95% confidence intervals for the low anchors -the points lower than 0 -and high anchors -the points higher than 0. The dashed lines represent the average estimates for the low and high anchors across all moderators of the meta-study.

div.head: Scaled Estimates
div.p: Note. The horizontal dashed lines represent the average estimates in the low and high anchor conditions. All values below 0 correspond to the low-anchoring condition and those above 0 are the high-anchoring condition. For each moderator, we provide the mean and 95% confidence intervals for low and high anchors in that particular condition. Thus, moderation of the anchoring effect would be reflected by the gap between the low and high anchors becoming greater or smaller between levels of the moderator.
In line with our pre-registered analysis plan, participants' responses were submitted to a mixed-effect linear regression. We begin with the following base model:

div.p: In Equation 1, α is the average response for all participants i and micro-study j;

where microstudy is simply an index of which cell of the between-participant factors that observation corresponds to (for details on this type of specification, see DeKay et al., 2022). We allow for random intercepts u 0i for participants. Additionally, we estimate a random slope u 1j on the anchoring-effect parameter to allow for variation in the anchoring effect across microstudies. 16 Anchor-item-level variability is accounted for in the x k term.

The x k term includes 7 anchor-item dummies to account for variability due to the particular anchoring questions in Table 7, the 10 coefficients for the 9 moderators (anchor extremity has a linear-coded predictor and a quadratic coded predictor -hence why there is one extra coefficient), and 10 interaction terms between the moderator variables and the Note. Estimated fixed-effect coefficients and 95% confidence intervals for each predictor in Equation 1. Grey points correspond to the main effect predictors in the model; these are presented for completeness but not relevant to the hypotheses. Black points correspond to the coefficients on the interaction term between each meta-study condition and the anchoring effect, and are the main tests of the meta-study moderators.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Below we discuss the consistencies and inconsistencies between the meta-study results and those of the meta-analysis.

Results consistent with the meta-analytic results. Overall, we observed six consistent findings between the two approaches on delay, different dimensions, directional anchors, precision, debiasing, and knowledge. We provide this categorization for efficiency but caution treating the results as definitively consistent or inconsistent. For example, while delay had a negative coefficient in the meta-analysis and a positive coefficient in the meta-study, both estimates included zero in their confidence intervals. Further, we recognize that although the meta-analysis examined knowledge in terms of objective knowledge differences, the meta-study employed subjective knowledge. Though these two may diverge (Alba & Hutchinson, 1987;Carlson, Vincent, Hardesty, & Bearden, 2009), their relationship with the magnitude of anchoring was consistent in this context.

Results inconsistent with the meta-analytic results. Overall, we observed three clearly inconsistent findings between the two approaches (i.e., extremity, incentives, and cognitive load). Whereas the meta-analysis indicated little moderation by extremity, results of the meta-study indicated a large increase in the anchoring effect when the anchors were more extreme. One important consideration is that the coding of extremity in the meta-analysis was based on the authors' explicit or implicit characterization of extremity.

Most studies in our meta-analysis had no explicitly-declared calibration pretest to evaluate the extent of an anchor's extremity for their sample population. Further, even within the meta-study, our characterization of the 3rd and 97th percentiles might not reflect the same magnitude of extremity as those used in the studies within the meta-analysis. Next, unlike the meta-analysis, in the meta-study we did not observe incentives attenuate the anchoring effect. It is possible that the presence of incentives gave no new strategies for addressing anchoring but instead only increased motivation (see Arkes, 1991). Finally, cognitive load may have increased effect sizes in the meta-study but not the meta-analysis because of mono-operation bias (Shadish, Cook, & Campbell, 2002) whereby our particular operationalization of cognitive load might increase anchoring effects, but this may not be the case for the myriad of different types of cognitive-load manipulations present across the anchoring literature that were all coalesced under our cognitive-load variable.
Overall, the meta-study provided some results that support the meta-analytic findings and other results that appeared inconsistent, which might reflect two possibilities.

The first possibility is that the meta-study was not representative of the studies in the literature. For instance, we used a memory-load task to induce cognitive load, whereas some studies in the literature used time pressure (e.g., Simonson & Drolet, 2004). In this way, the meta-study may also suffer from a mono-operation bias in which it only adopts one manifestation of a given manipulation, and thus its conclusions may be limited to the approaches we adopted (Shadish et al., 2002). Another dimension of representativeness could be that the online participants in the meta-study were substantially different than those across the literature, which included a mixture of field, laboratory, and online participants. In the Online Appendix E we report coefficients for the exploratory moderators from the meta-analysis and do see significant moderation as a function of whether the study was run with an online panel or in-person participants.

The second explanation for the inconsistencies could be a combination of publication bias along with other non-reporting biases relevant to the meta-analytic database. That is, incomplete reporting of nonsignificant moderation in published studies (i.e., collapsing over levels of a moderator when reporting results), suppression of failed replications, or other findings that contradict existing theories could all lead to an artificial inflation or deflation of effect size differences (Coburn & Vevea, 2015;Vevea, Coburn, & Sutton, 2019). The advantage of meta-studies is that they give every moderator equivalent opportunity under the assumption of equivalent operationalization of the manipulations. This means that results cannot be due to publication incentives or outcome/moderator reporting bias.

div.head: General Discussion
div.p: How do people make numeric estimates? Whether wondering how much to bid in an eBay auction, contemplating how many people will support a policy, or assessing how long the commute to work will take, these estimates have important implications for numerous decisions. The anchoring literature offers one answer: people use recently-encountered numeric stimuli as an input to these judgments. Despite the generality of this literature, there remain numerous unanswered questions.

We caution that while our meta-analysis and meta-study are the most comprehensive exploration of moderators of the anchoring effect to date, the results are by no means definitive. Anchoring is an extremely broad research area, both conceptually and substantively. Given the breadth of the anchoring literature, it is necessary to be cautious about assumptions of generality from studies that involve only a particular anchoring stimulus and a particular operation of a moderator. As such, we encourage researchers and practitioners to use the current manuscript as starting-point for future lines of anchoring research rather than as the catalog of the "average effect size" for each moderator.

div.head: What is an Anchoring Effect?
div.p: While the anchoring effect is an exceptionally large literature that spans the behavioral, and related, sciences, its theoretical space is quite fragmented. After 50 years of research on this phenomenon, there is no one theory that provides a parsimonious explanation of all of the latent drivers that produce this seminal effect -and there may not need be one (see below). We suggest that the features of this literature that have facilitated its proliferation are also what has prevented it from reaching theoretical clarity in terms of clearly differentiated characteristics for the categorization of an anchoring effect.

The range of what counts as anchoring is extremely wide. In the current manuscript, we operationalized anchoring effects as cases where decision-makers are presented a single number before making a numeric judgment. Across the literature, we argue that there are three major paradigms of anchoring that vary in how informative the anchors are intended to be, across which we tested the impact of non-diagnostic (vs. diagnostic) anchors. In paradigm one, people make a numeric estimate following a comparative question (i.e., higher or lower) against a randomly-determined number. In paradigm two, people make a numeric estimate following exposure to incidental (e.g., primed) numbers in the environment. In paradigm three, anchors are presented in contexts in which they may have normative value (e.g., a list price of a house). 17 While the literature has an inclusive structure for characterizing anchoring effects, we suggest that it may be more beneficial for scientific advancement and practical utilization of anchoring effects to instead characterize anchoring as a class of effects rather than as an individual phenomenon. As an example, consider two cases: anchoring on general knowledge questions such as the length of the Mississippi River (e.g., Jacowitz & Kahneman, 1995) and anchoring on the list price of a house when making housing-price judgments (e.g., Northcraft & Neale, 1987) (i.e., paradigms one and three). These paradigms both involve assimilation in the direction of the anchoring values, but the underlying processes driving these effects likely differ substantially.

div.head: Evaluating Existing Theories
div.p: In Table 1 in the introduction, we outlined the predictions for each of the seven existing theories within the anchoring literature. We should note a few important points.

First, most theories do not speak explicitly to all of the moderators in the anchoring literature. Anchoring-and-Adjustment, the oldest account, is tied with Selective Accessibility for the most explicit predictions at eight, whereas newer accounts such as Noise Theory only make explicit predictions about three moderators. It's not pragmatic to count winners and losers because there is a potential trade-off between how accurate each theory is and how much theoretical space it covers with explicit predictions. For example,
whereas Anchoring-and-Adjustment is incorrect about some moderators (e.g., directional

anchors, transparently random anchors), Noise Theory and Scale Distortion have accurate, but more limited, predictions. Adjudicating theoretical breadth versus accuracy is likely quite difficult and not the intended goal of the current manuscript. Additionally, it is arguable that the two most recently-proposed accounts, Noise Theory and Extremeness Aversion, may serve as addenda to the initial Anchoring-and-Adjustment theory rather than as stand-alone theories, and as such make the same predictions as
Anchoring-and-Adjustment for most moderators.

As another reason to avoid merely counting number of predictions, we caution that some theories have received far more attention than others or may have other relevant process tests. For example, the Selective Accessibility Hypothesis has been applied in a much broader set of paradigms and moderators than other, newer theories, and has assessed its mechanisms with additional reaction-time measures. Further, even though the Selective Accessibility Hypothesis made many correct predictions (e.g., delay), it is not always internally consistent. For example, Strack and Mussweiler (1997) Mussweiler and Englich (2005) argue that something far more incidental like a subliminal prime does activate anchor-consistent knowledge. Another reason for not picking winners is that some theories use process evidence that is not mutually comparable across theories and uses alternative measures such as reaction time (e.g., Mussweiler & Strack, 2000b). However, we should note that some of this process evidence has failed to replicate in high-powered replication attempts (Harris et al., 2019).

Even within a given moderator, the exact operationalization might yield meaningfully different results. For example, some of the inconsistent empirical results between the meta-analysis and meta-study may reflect differences in how a moderator was operationalized (i.e., mono-operation bias in the meta-study). Within the meta-analysis, some moderators received little attention in the literature or had minimal variability in the studies, which we discuss in the future directions later. Other moderators had the opposite problem and were so inconsistent across studies that inference is limited. For example, because most studies using extreme anchors did not include a calibration study, the particular amount of extremity was likely sampled from the researchers' own intuitions. Another challenge is that existing theories were not developed to accommodate the numerous moderators in the literature, which is evidenced by the number of blank cells in (Gholson & Barker, 1985).

We do not intend for the above discussion to disparage existing theories. Instead, we recognize that the challenge of theorizing about the anchoring effect is inherent in the fact that the operationalization of the anchoring effect is both vague and extremely domain general. That is, one reason for the proliferation of theory around this phenomenon is due to the lack of clarity in defining the conceptual boundaries for the effect. In the following sections, we aim to provide guidance both for the conceptualization of the phenomenon and the defining of theoretical structures.

div.head: Guidance for Theory Development
div.p: In the sections below we begin by offering recommendations about how to improve testing existing theories. Afterwards, we integrate insights from the current review to recommend how future theories should attempt to encapsulate anchoring.

div.head: Salience.
div.p: In terms of salience, while there has already been sufficient work regarding incidental anchoring (Brewer & Chapman, 2002;R. A. Klein et al., 2018), there has been far less attention on temporal delays between the anchor and judgment (Mussweiler, 2001;Yoon & Fong, 2019), optimal exposure time to anchors, and the role of competing information in the decision environment. More experimental investigations that test the degree of delay between the anchor presentation and the target judgment could be useful for disentangling existing theories. These existing theories differ in their reliance on lower-level versus higher-level cognitions. For example, in terms of lower-level cognitions, Many existing studies may direct attention to the anchor via a comparison question (e.g., Jacowitz & Kahneman, 1995) while others have the anchor embedded along with other numeric and textual information (e.g., list prices were embedded among a whole portfolio of relevant information for real-estate appraisals Northcraft & Neale, 1987). What types of competing information detract from versus enhance the salience and impact of anchors?

div.head: Inference.
div.p: How and when people draw inferences across contexts remains a key direction for future research. Numerous instructions and manipulations have aimed to separate anchoring from a conversational inference interpretation (Grice, 1975;Schwarz, 1994) by signaling explicitly or implicitly that the anchor lacks diagnostic information. But, the argument for inference making is that decision-makers use inferential cues because more often than not, information is presented for a reason (Grice, 1975). While there is extensive research in social psychology about how individuals derive inference, we encourage anchoring researchers to start with the minimalist hypothesis proposed by McKoon and Ratcliff (1992) to explain how decision-makers generate the minimal necessary inferences to bridge a coherence gap. That is, when there is a logical step missing in a sequence, the mind will seek to fill that gap with the simplest explanation to make the sequence coherent. For example, when judging the length of the Mississippi River and considering the comparison question about whether the river is greater than or less than 3,500 miles, there is a gap about why that 3,500 is part of the question. The minimal inference is that the 3,500 miles number has some relevance to the true answer.

Existing moderators aim to fill this gap by, for example, telling/showing participants explicitly that the 3,500 was derived randomly (i.e., transparently random anchors). Other do so implicitly by warning against anchors (i.e., debiasing) or reducing the decision-relevance of the anchor (i.e., diagnositicity stimulus/dimension). In the current meta-analysis, we did not have enough precision in the literature to tease apart the exact roles of the anchor stimulus/dimension, but encourage further exploration. In particular, how similar/different (Evers, Imas, & Kang, 2022) does the anchor need to be to generate an inference that it is a diagnostic cue for the judgment?

These inferences also likely differ between the reviewed anchoring paradigms. For paradigm one, there are likely not a wide array of inferences because the paradigm is controlled and simplistic. Thus, for paradigm one, we encourage researchers to explore how the inference affects beliefs both about the central tendency of the anchor and the distribution of possible true values (Turner & Schley, 2016). This is relevant to a range of anchoring theories. For example, according to the Attitudinal Perspective (Wegener et al., 2010), anchoring occurring via central route processing should influence the strength of that belief which should present itself as having a tighter distribution of potential values.

This range of potential values is also relevant to Anchoring-and-Adjustment (Quattrone et al., 1984), Extremeness Aversion (Lewis et al., 2019) For paradigm three, which contains anchors embedded in a contextualized environment (e.g., legal settings, real estate prices), we expect to see a much wider range of inferences. For example, past work has looked at signals of confidence or accuracy imbued with precise anchors (Jerez-Fernandez et al., 2014;Smith & Marshall, 2017;Zhang & Schwarz, 2013). Similarly, does the extremity of the anchor change the perceived credibility of its source? As another example, consider the case of first offers in negotiations (e.g., Galinsky & Mussweiler, 2001). Depending on other contextual cues, the anchor could be seen as the starting point for the seller, or the lowest reasonable offer they are willing to take, or the seller's belief about the highest price the buyer may be willing to pay. Thus, for paradigm three, theories can better attempt to accommodate the range of potential inferences derived from anchors in each decision context.

div.head: Memory.
div.p: There exist far more potential moderators in the space of memory that have yet to be explored. So far, anchoring research has mostly considered the perceived anchor extremity (e.g., comparing the anchor against exemplars already within memory) and decision-maker's certainty in their judgments (Smith et al., 2013;Turner & Schley, 2016).

Both of these factors serve as inputs to the range of plausible values for a target judgment (C.-Y. Lee & Morewedge, 2022;Lewis et al., 2019). However, there is a difference between the total information about a target judgment stored in the associative network within memory and what is retrieved/activated via spreading activation Collins and Loftus (1975).

And, what gets activated is logically important for how decision-makers construct their judgments (The Selective Accessibility Hypothesis and the Activation Account Chapman & Johnson, 1999;Strack & Mussweiler, 1997). While our meta-analysis provides evidence that the amount of total knowledge someone has about a target judgment reduces the magnitude of the anchoring effect, does the particular type of knowledge in memory matter (Tannenbaum, Fox, & Ülkümen, 2017)? Epistemic uncertainty is a case where, for example, information about the length of the Mississippi River is unknown to the decision-maker but is knowable via an internet search. Conversely, aleatory uncertainty is a case where, for example, the true value of a house price is unknown to the decision-maker and is not knowable via search -rather the eventual selling price for a house is due in part to stochastic processes. This differentiation is likely relevant to Noise Theory (C.-Y. Lee & Morewedge, 2022) and would also impact perceptions of what anchors are perceived as extreme values (Lewis et al., 2019;Mussweiler & Strack, 2001a;Quattrone et al., 1984).

If all theories agree that the anchor is providing/activating knowledge to some extent, then understanding decision-maker's prior knowledge is pertinent for understanding the theoretical mechanisms by which judgments shift in the presence of the information being provided by the anchor. We strongly encourage future research to better catalog not just how much knowledge decision-makers have about a target judgment, but what types of knowledge. For instance, there is a long tradition of differences in activation and use of episodic (i.e., experienced) versus semantic (i.e., general knowledge) exemplars in memory (Tulving, 2002). As an illustration of these possibilities, consider an anchor in the context of Seattle's highest summer temperature. The impact of a high anchor may have a stronger impact on someone who has lived through a Seattle summer (i.e., episodic) relative to someone with only semantic knowledge of Seattle's weather.

div.head: Depth of Information Processing.
div.p: If anchors are non-diagnostic cues that get conflated into subsequent judgments (at least in paradigms one and two) then in what ways do slower, more deliberative, regulatory aspects of cognition (e.g., System 2 processing) play into their use (Evans, 2008 understanding what is the minimal amount of processing required to observe an anchoring effect. For example, investigators might explore a continuum of no, low, moderate, and high load rather than just no load versus high load.

One greatly overlooked aspect of depth-of-information-processing is whether increasing/decreasing processing capacity influences attention to the anchoring stimulus (i.e., Salience), what information is derived from the anchor (i.e., Inference), and what information from long-term memory is accessibility at the moment of the judgment (i.e., Memory). Said another way, a given moderator related to processing capacity may impact any/all of the other components, and thus experimental approaches will need to more carefully dissociate, via controls and measurement, exactly where the information-processing-capacity manipulation is operating.

div.head: Updating Existing Theories and Introducing New Theories.
div.p: As evident from table 1, existing theories do not encapsulate all current moderators, let alone some new moderators proposed above. To move our understanding of anchoring effects forward, existing theories will need to be updated to be more comprehensive, or replaced by newer, more comprehensive theories. Below we lay out recommendations for updated and new theories of anchoring:

1) Tie theories to paradigm: As discussed in the introduction, paradigms one, two, and three likely reflect three analogous patterns of results but are likely produced by distinct psychological processes. Most current theories were developed primarily using studies that employ paradigm one, but have been generalized to explain phenomena using paradigm three. We recommend that updated and new theories should situate themselves within paradigm one or paradigm three. Only after validating the mechanisms within that paradigm can that theory be extended to apply to other paradigms. For example, it may be that the best theory for paradigm one may not be appropriate for explain outcomes from paradigm two or paradigm three.

2) Specify theories with regard to each anchoring component: Our review of the literature highlights that existing theories and past moderators correspond to four components of anchoring: salience, inference making, memory, and depth of information processing. While we do not believe that anchoring theories need to be able to make predictions across paradigms, within a paradigm, theories should be comprehensive about how anchors operate based on boundaries and processes outlined by all of the four components. This is necessary for theory testing as it allows for direct comparison of predictions across theories. Additionally, this completeness enables potential falsification of theories. If there are likely many separable inputs into an anchoring effect, then specifying, measuring, and controlling for other processes is necessary for testing the validity of a focal hypothesized process.

3) Process evidence and individual differences: Once theories have been properly specified within each component, collecting process evidence for a given theory becomes more straightforward. For example, if researchers wanted to explore the range-of-plausible-values-mechanism within Anchoring-and-Adjustment, simply asking participants for this range would not be sufficient for identifying theoretical mechanisms because this judgment is likely the consequence multiple processes. But, having defined how this range relates to decision-makers' memory and the depth of their information processing should facilitate measurements of unique processes that should make theories more falsifiable. For example, if there is an "adjustment" mechanism (Epley & Gilovich, 2001), there should be direct evidence of incremental iterations in the judgment. Similarly, if the anchor activates information consistent with the anchor value, either spontaneously via the comparison question (Chapman & Johnson, 1999) or through a confirmatory hypothesis test (Strack & Mussweiler, 1997), this difference should be evident in decision-makers' memories for how they formed the judgment. And as discussed above with regard to inference making, what makes decision-makers infer a particular anchor as extreme (Lewis et al., 2019) or feel more or less certain about the judgment task (C.-Y. Lee & Morewedge, 2022) likely depends on the specific inferences they derive.

Related to process evidence, another avenue greatly understudied within this literature is the role of individual differences. However, we caution that instead of connecting individual differences to the extent of anchoring directly. Ideally the literature would thread individual differences through each of the four component processes that contribute to anchoring. Individuals differ in the extent to which they attend to numbers in a decision environment (i.e., influencing the salience Fagerlin et al., 2007), the likelihood they engage in inference making (Uleman, Adil Saribay, & Gonzalez, 2008), how and how much they retrieve from memory (Miller & Unsworth, 2018), and the depth of information processing applied to a judgment (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986).

div.head: 4) Refine and formalize theories:
div.p: To date, there have been limited attempts to mathematically model anchoring effects (Lieder, Griffiths, M. Huys, & Goodman, 2018;Turner & Schley, 2016). If anchoring is as pervasive and influential as the introductions of many anchoring papers purport, then an eventual goal of theory should be prediction.

Numeric anchoring involves a quantitative anchor and a quantitative final judgment/estimate. Qualitative theories are a good starting point. But, anchoring is well equipped for formal models for theory testing and prediction.

div.head: Methodological implications for researchers.
div.p: The present research also offers insights for how researchers may approach running anchoring studies. For example, researchers may use the estimated effect sizes from the meta-analysis as a baseline when determining sample sizes for future studies. Moreover, for study design, one big issue alluded to earlier is the limited number of papers explicitly running calibration studies prior to the main experiments. To know whether an anchor is high, low, extreme, or plausible, it is necessary to evaluate decision-maker's pre-existing knowledge about a given decision domain in addition to the range of knowledge in the population. This calibration is a necessary step for internal validity of anchoring studies, particularly when attempting to develop and test theories. We would also strongly encourage greater stimulus sampling, including from different anchoring values and questions, in subsequent research to be able to fully map anchoring effects across its "myriad of domains" highlighted in the introduction of many anchoring papers.

We also provide some caution in how researchers choose their dependent variables for anchoring. As discussed in the meta-analytic methodology, there exist multiple types of anchoring-effect dependent variables that were not possible to be coalesced into a single meta-analytic database such as high versus low and high/low versus control. The most common dependent variable in this literature is the traditional numeric estimate typically following exposure to either a low or high anchor. This pairing has the most interpretable treatment effect as it represents the relative difference in judgment as a function of the level of the anchor, whereas versions comparing an anchor to a no-anchor control only represent half of the effect (see Online Appendix C). Using correlations has been useful when anchors are sampled from a distribution (Ariely et al., 2003). However, given the above discussion about the necessity of calibration studies, and that the correlational studies do not use them, said studies become difficult to interpret. Moreover, in our analysis of the literature, we found that the anchor-estimate gap is the most problematic for inference. First, each gap's overall magnitude is not meaningful. That is, the gap only indicates relative increases or decreases in the magnitude of the effect as a function of an orthogonal moderator.

Additionally, results using this dependent variable were the most different from those presented here in the main text (see Online Appendix H). Lastly, recent evidence suggests that the construct validity of the anchor-estimate gap is, at best, weakly correlated with anchoring, and at worst, strongly negatively correlated with anchoring [Blinded for review, 2025]. Given the above limitations, we would encourage future research to mostly focus on the high versus low and the high/low versus control experimental setups.

div.head: Guidance for Practitioners
div.p: Beyond establishing the robustness of anchoring across domains (e.g., law, management, economics, and marketing), the results on boundary conditions in this manuscript suggest three recommendations for practitioners who may attempt to use anchors in managerial settings. The first direction concerns finding "optimal" values to use in policy and firm settings (Goswami & Urminsky, 2016). That is, despite the prevalence of anchoring, there is very little research attempting to quantify the effect so that practitioners can select optimal anchors (Turner & Schley, 2016). This question of optimal anchor values relates to anchor extremity: at what threshold do anchors no longer lead to assimilation? In the meta-analysis we found no consistent moderation of extremity but found an increase with more extreme anchors in the meta-study. To understand the role of extremity a more effective study design requires assessing anchor values at each level of a baseline distribution -rather than at just the 3rd/97th, 15th/85th, and 30th/70th
percentiles. This would offer a fuller picture by mapping the extremity continuum and identifying optimal anchor values.
Second, we would also encourage practitioners to explore which features of their particular decision-making context make an anchor appear more or less diagnostic.

Moderators related to dimension and transparent randomness had some of the largest impacts on effect sizes in the meta-analysis and meta-study. If these moderators have the large potential impact for organizations and policy agents, then understanding how these moderators operate and their boundary conditions are necessary for developing effective anchor-based interventions.

Third, we should offer a cautionary observation about the potential risks of using anchors. It was rare to observe a negative impact of anchoring (i.e., a reversal), suggesting that employing anchors might not immediately backfire. However, in the primary meta-analysis of high-versus-low anchors 7.5% of the sample had negative effect sizes. It would be prudent for practitioners to be cognizant of under what conditions those negative effects could occur. For example, in line with the inference-making portion of our above anchoring framework, there is the potential for decision-makers to make an inference that the firm is using the anchor in a coercive manner, potentially leading to consumer reactance.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: 50 years ago, researchers asked participants about the percentage of African countries in the United Nations (Tversky & Kahneman, 1974). Since that investigation, there has been thousands of investigations across domains, at least seven theories proposed, multiple replications, and likely countless classroom demonstrations. This manuscript organizes the theoretical underpinnings of numeric anchoring effects with a large-scale empirical test of canonical theoretical moderators, and proposes a new framework of underlying components and paradigms of anchoring effects. As anchoring research continues, it must be mindful of both the way it describes the processes of interest and the full theoretical space it occupies. Else, anchoring can apply to almost everything per its status as a robust class of effects yet fail to describe anything alone adequately.

Wegener et al. (2010)'s Attitudinal Account argues that the anchor can be seen as a persuasive message whereby the decision maker may derive meaningful inferences like any other persuasive cue. Lewis et al. (2019)'s account supposes that individuals make an inference about whether the anchor value is "extreme" and the extent to which the anchor is perceived as extreme depends on contextualizing factors in the decision environment. The key question is which inferences are influencing estimates at each level of any given moderator?

As an additional complication, we note that even when a theory could be applied to a moderator, there may still be ambiguity about how each theory's mechanism(s) may operate under different conditions or what the baseline conditions are assumed to be. For example, cognitive load may either lead to increased anchoring effects or decreased anchoring effects according to Numeric Priming. That is, if load prevents consideration of alternative numeric inputs or responses, there may be greater anchoring. However, if load hinders processing of the anchor by commanding the decision-maker's attention, there may be less anchoring. In short, theory testing and pruning becomes infeasible when theories are not completely clear about the boundaries of the mechanisms within the theory

Numeric Priming and Scale Distortion merely require perception of stimuli. On the other hand, Selective Accessibility requires higher-level cognitions through hypothesis testing, and Extremeness Aversion involves an intermediary judgment of what makes something "extreme." In principle, different amounts of delay manipulate the salience of the anchor in decision-makers' percept. Further, while evidence from the meta-analysis suggests that anchoring effects do not appear reliable with incidental/primed exposure, what is the minimum amount of exposure/salience needed to produce a reliable effect? Is there a plateau for exposure? Finally, researchers should experiment with richer environments with information from competing attributes that could reduce the relative salience of the anchor.

In Online Appendix I, we present an analysis of the influence of this winsorization decision by re-estimating the following results with winsorized thresholds from the 90th to the 100th percentiles and find largely consistent results. Additionally, we deviate slightly from our pre-registration by not including the variable for item order as a predictor. We chose to remove it because it did not align with the other moderators from our meta-analysis. Results are extremely similar with the inclusion of this predictor.
We did not include a random intercept u 0j on the anchoring effect parameter because this parameter estimate would become singular. This implies that there is a high degree of covariation between

We explored segmenting the meta-analysis to investigate each moderator within each of paradigm one, two, and three separately. Even with such a large database, empirical investigations would have been statistically weak due to the much more sparse distribution of moderators within paradigms 2 and 3.
